description: Technicians and administrators alike need tools to diagnose computer problems, centrally manage encryption and recovery keys, provide consistency in user settings, provide application co-existence and more. These are some of the topics that we will tackle in our series on MDOP.
name: Microsoft Desktop Optimization Pack
subtitle: MDOP

episodes.description: Technicians and administrators alike need tools to diagnose computer problems, centrally manage encryption and recovery keys, provide consistency in user settings, provide application co-existence and more. These are some of the topics that we will tackle in our series on MDOP.
episodes.title: Overview
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:03.698 --> 00:00:04.216
We're here

2
00:00:04.216 --> 00:00:07.860
to present to you an overview of
the Microsoft Desktop Optimization Pack.

3
00:00:07.860 --> 00:00:10.260
This is gonna be a new tech
skills show for us, so

4
00:00:10.260 --> 00:00:13.730
that we can actually help you understand
what this product is really all about, and

5
00:00:13.730 --> 00:00:16.410
here to help us out better
is gonna be Mr Wes Bryan.

6
00:00:16.410 --> 00:00:21.060
Wes, who is this particular show really
for, and what topics will we be covering?

7
00:00:21.060 --> 00:00:24.350
>> Well, this is an interesting tech
skill, because one of the things you might

8
00:00:24.350 --> 00:00:29.100
find out there is, there is plenty of, I
would say, textual information about MDOP.

9
00:00:29.100 --> 00:00:33.560
But one of the things it's lacking,
is more video content, and

10
00:00:33.560 --> 00:00:36.380
it is something that,
it does rear its head from time to time.

11
00:00:36.380 --> 00:00:40.190
So this going to be focused on anybody
that wants a little bit better of

12
00:00:40.190 --> 00:00:43.590
an understanding of Microsoft's Enterprise
suite of technologies,

13
00:00:43.590 --> 00:00:47.710
known as
the Microsoft Desktop Optimization Pack.

14
00:00:47.710 --> 00:00:51.370
It helps you to manage things
like the user experience.

15
00:00:51.370 --> 00:00:55.930
For instance, desktop applications, things
like virtualization, as well as managing

16
00:00:55.930 --> 00:00:59.820
a lot of the features that you'll find
inside of your Windows environments.

17
00:00:59.820 --> 00:01:01.790
Keep in mind that the viewer
is gonna be introduced to,

18
00:01:01.790 --> 00:01:03.220
not just a single technology.

19
00:01:03.220 --> 00:01:06.680
I know we call this
Microsoft Desktop Optimization Pack,

20
00:01:06.680 --> 00:01:09.470
but keep in mind it could
also be renamed a toolkit,

21
00:01:09.470 --> 00:01:14.260
because it has many different applications
or products, all bundled into one.

22
00:01:14.260 --> 00:01:18.020
For instance, user experience
virtualization is gonna be one of those

23
00:01:18.020 --> 00:01:21.290
things that we'll be looking at,
sometimes called UEV.

24
00:01:21.290 --> 00:01:24.640
It's a way that I can take settings,
and I can virtualize them, and

25
00:01:24.640 --> 00:01:27.950
have those settings follow me
when I go to different computers.

26
00:01:27.950 --> 00:01:29.330
It's a real handy tool.

27
00:01:29.330 --> 00:01:30.203
Things like AppV.

28
00:01:30.203 --> 00:01:31.230
Maybe you've heard of this.

29
00:01:31.230 --> 00:01:33.100
This is the Application Virtualization.

30
00:01:33.100 --> 00:01:37.510
I need to virtualize an application,
but maybe I don't want to put it into

31
00:01:37.510 --> 00:01:41.200
a hypervisor, and, you know, virtualize
the whole entire operating system.

32
00:01:41.200 --> 00:01:44.990
So this is a good way that you could take
applications, and in a more modular sense,

33
00:01:44.990 --> 00:01:47.660
you can virtualise each
individual one if you need to.

34
00:01:47.660 --> 00:01:50.533
Some of the other topics that
we'll be looking at, is MBAM.

35
00:01:50.533 --> 00:01:53.641
That is, the Microsoft BitLocker,
an administration and

36
00:01:53.641 --> 00:01:55.141
monitoring kit you can use.

37
00:01:55.141 --> 00:01:59.467
It's, maybe you've heard of BitLocker
inside of the Windows operating system,

38
00:01:59.467 --> 00:02:03.975
well, BitLocker, unless you're in group
policy, is kind of a decentralized type of

39
00:02:03.975 --> 00:02:07.770
management system, and it's usually
on a computer to computer basis.

40
00:02:07.770 --> 00:02:11.740
But what this does, the MBAM Software,
is it allows you to scale up to

41
00:02:11.740 --> 00:02:16.170
large enterprises, and
centrally manage BitLocker keys and

42
00:02:16.170 --> 00:02:19.890
BitLocker encryptions that are in
your Enterprise level environment.

43
00:02:19.890 --> 00:02:23.570
We'll look at another tool, that,
one of my personal favorites in the MDOP

44
00:02:23.570 --> 00:02:26.930
platform, is something known as
the Diagnostic and Recovery Toolkit.

45
00:02:26.930 --> 00:02:29.120
And this is a great way that,
like it says,

46
00:02:29.120 --> 00:02:32.470
you can diagnose different problems that
happen inside of the Windows environment.

47
00:02:32.470 --> 00:02:35.230
So, we've got more than just that,
but keep in mind

48
00:02:35.230 --> 00:02:40.240
that some of the topics that you can see
inside of the MDOP series coming up.

49
00:02:40.240 --> 00:02:43.980
>> Now Wes, is there any particular
exam that's associated with this?

50
00:02:43.980 --> 00:02:46.700
Or are we just really talking
about learning the skills itself?

51
00:02:46.700 --> 00:02:49.920
>> I would say the latter's probably gonna
be true, we're gonna be looking more at

52
00:02:49.920 --> 00:02:53.040
the skills that you need, and
just kind of looking at the technology,

53
00:02:53.040 --> 00:02:56.660
not really exam-centric on this one,
but I will throw a word of caution.

54
00:02:56.660 --> 00:03:00.080
One of the things that I've seen, and
if you've taken previous Windows client

55
00:03:00.080 --> 00:03:04.260
certifications, MDOP sometimes
does rear it's head on the exam.

56
00:03:04.260 --> 00:03:08.000
So, while this isn't specific to any
certification, keep in mind any time

57
00:03:08.000 --> 00:03:11.910
you're managing a Windows 10 client
operating system, if you're studying for

58
00:03:11.910 --> 00:03:15.260
that very certification,
this can help to expand your knowledge.

59
00:03:15.260 --> 00:03:17.955
So, if that's something you wanna
know a little bit more about,

60
00:03:17.955 --> 00:03:20.405
the Microsoft Desktop Optimization Pack,
stick around,

61
00:03:20.405 --> 00:03:21.589
cuz we got a lot more to come.

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Wes begin their Microsoft Desktop Optimization Pack Series by exploring Bitlocker Admin and Monitoring components. This includes the Domain Controller, Management Workstations, Database Server, Administration and Monitoring Server, and MBAM Client.
episodes.title: MBAM Components
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.076 --> 00:00:10.076
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.104 --> 00:00:13.965
All right, good evening everyone and

3
00:00:13.965 --> 00:00:16.965
welcome comes into another
exciting episode of IT PRO.TV.

4
00:00:16.965 --> 00:00:20.595
I'm your host Daniel Lowrie, and
in today's episode we are beginning

5
00:00:20.595 --> 00:00:24.505
our series on
Microsoft's Desk-top Optimization Package.

6
00:00:24.505 --> 00:00:27.205
Joining me in the studio to help
us with that very endeavor and

7
00:00:27.205 --> 00:00:29.990
be our guiding star Is our good friend,
Mr. Wes Bryan.

8
00:00:29.990 --> 00:00:31.840
Wes, welcome to the show,
how's it going today?

9
00:00:31.840 --> 00:00:32.720
>> It's going great Dan.

10
00:00:32.720 --> 00:00:35.930
And as always, it's good to be
here in the studios at IT PRO.TV.

11
00:00:35.930 --> 00:00:40.800
And that's right, we have a bunch of
different technologies that are bundled

12
00:00:40.800 --> 00:00:46.050
up in MDOP, like you heard Dan say,
the Microsoft Desktop Optimization Pack.

13
00:00:46.050 --> 00:00:48.920
And one of the first of those
components that we're gonna be diving

14
00:00:48.920 --> 00:00:52.420
into is one that, well,
when it comes to MDOP in general,

15
00:00:52.420 --> 00:00:56.350
well, we'll just step back here before
we get into something known as MBAND.

16
00:00:56.350 --> 00:01:02.230
Microsoft desktop optimization pack, it's
got a lot of different utilities in it and

17
00:01:02.230 --> 00:01:06.510
it's really only available to
a select demographic of people,

18
00:01:06.510 --> 00:01:08.130
customers if you will, by Microsoft.

19
00:01:08.130 --> 00:01:12.290
So it can be a little bit challenging when
it comes to learning the topics out there.

20
00:01:12.290 --> 00:01:15.400
Now out on Tech Net they got all
kinds of white papers you can

21
00:01:15.400 --> 00:01:17.718
read about the different
components in here.

22
00:01:17.718 --> 00:01:22.430
But there again, as far as
the technology itself, you have to be

23
00:01:22.430 --> 00:01:27.710
a software assurance customer or a volume
licensed customer to get access to MDOT or

24
00:01:27.710 --> 00:01:31.690
you have to have an access to
an MSDN subscription there, and

25
00:01:31.690 --> 00:01:34.150
then you can get access
to the software itself.

26
00:01:34.150 --> 00:01:38.270
So what we wanna do is we kinda wanna
walk you through, in this series,

27
00:01:38.270 --> 00:01:42.160
through all of the different components
that you'll find, or the technologies,

28
00:01:42.160 --> 00:01:44.570
I should say, inside of MDOP.

29
00:01:44.570 --> 00:01:49.260
And the first one that we're gonna be
working with today is something known as

30
00:01:49.260 --> 00:01:53.510
Microsoft's BitLocker,
administration and monitoring.

31
00:01:53.510 --> 00:01:56.690
Now, you might have heard
it abbreviated MBAM.

32
00:01:56.690 --> 00:02:00.250
Now, don't get that confused with
another MBAM, and in fact, Dan and

33
00:02:00.250 --> 00:02:01.300
I were talking about this.

34
00:02:01.300 --> 00:02:04.620
When you do a Google search for MBAM,
you're going to find Malwarebytes.

35
00:02:04.620 --> 00:02:07.780
Malwarebytes is what a lot of
times we've known over the past,

36
00:02:07.780 --> 00:02:11.360
gosh I wanna say decade or
so has been the acronym.

37
00:02:11.360 --> 00:02:15.180
But MBAM for us is gonna be bitlocker
administration and monitoring.

38
00:02:15.180 --> 00:02:17.810
And that's what we're
gonna start out with.

39
00:02:17.810 --> 00:02:23.350
This is a great suite of Enterprise
level technology, if you will,

40
00:02:23.350 --> 00:02:28.330
that allows you to centrally
manage BitLocker in general.

41
00:02:28.330 --> 00:02:31.320
Now, if you aren't
familiar with BitLocker,

42
00:02:31.320 --> 00:02:33.360
we'll just gonna brief you over on that.

43
00:02:33.360 --> 00:02:38.190
Definitely go back and take a look at some
of our Windows Client episodes out there

44
00:02:38.190 --> 00:02:42.300
cuz we definitely cover BitLocker
from the client side pretty in-depth.

45
00:02:42.300 --> 00:02:47.320
But remember, that is Microsoft's
drive encryption technology, and

46
00:02:47.320 --> 00:02:49.800
when it comes to drive encryption,
we need certain

47
00:02:49.800 --> 00:02:54.080
passwords to be able to access these
drives after they're encrypted.

48
00:02:54.080 --> 00:02:58.570
And one of the things that can
potentially happen is, it could become

49
00:02:58.570 --> 00:03:03.380
nightmare the more and more of your
devices that you implement BitLocker on.

50
00:03:03.380 --> 00:03:07.520
So because of that fact we
need a place where it's not

51
00:03:07.520 --> 00:03:10.430
decentralized in any way and
it's just centralized.

52
00:03:10.430 --> 00:03:15.640
And if you have 10 devices,
if you 100 devices, 500 devices,

53
00:03:15.640 --> 00:03:20.680
you want to be able to manage the
encryption keys and also provide a way for

54
00:03:20.680 --> 00:03:26.140
recovery if somebody happens to
lose access to their password.

55
00:03:26.140 --> 00:03:27.900
Well do they lose access to their data?

56
00:03:27.900 --> 00:03:31.610
Well for the most part if we don't
have some kind of recovery in place,

57
00:03:31.610 --> 00:03:35.870
then they will lose access to
their information and Dan I know,

58
00:03:35.870 --> 00:03:39.270
we have talked about this before there are
a couple of things that go on in security,

59
00:03:39.270 --> 00:03:40.840
well there's quite a few
things that go on in security.

60
00:03:40.840 --> 00:03:43.950
But two of the things we have,
the more secure you make something

61
00:03:43.950 --> 00:03:47.560
well sometimes it can make it
challenging on the end users as well.

62
00:03:47.560 --> 00:03:50.100
So we want to implement encryption but

63
00:03:50.100 --> 00:03:54.040
at the same time we want people to
have access to their information.

64
00:03:54.040 --> 00:03:58.750
If, they first of all if they need it,

65
00:03:58.750 --> 00:04:01.160
second of all if they
happen to lose passwords,

66
00:04:01.160 --> 00:04:05.290
we want a way that they can recover
that information so they regain access.

67
00:04:05.290 --> 00:04:08.050
So, Dan one of the first things we're
gonna do is we're gonna look at some of

68
00:04:08.050 --> 00:04:11.010
the components that we have inside
of the Microsoft BitLocker,

69
00:04:11.010 --> 00:04:12.780
administration and monitoring.

70
00:04:12.780 --> 00:04:16.690
>> Yeah, Wes, you mentioned central or
centralization, should I say,

71
00:04:16.690 --> 00:04:18.120
we don't want things decentralized.

72
00:04:18.120 --> 00:04:19.800
And when I think Microsoft and

73
00:04:19.800 --> 00:04:23.780
decentralization, I'm thinking server,
I'm thinking domain controller.

74
00:04:23.780 --> 00:04:27.400
And that's obviously one of probably the
biggest critical portion to this system.

75
00:04:27.400 --> 00:04:28.020
>> That's right Dan,

76
00:04:28.020 --> 00:04:30.760
we do want centralized administration
when it comes to MBAM.

77
00:04:30.760 --> 00:04:33.740
So let's go ahead and look at some of
the components that we have here so

78
00:04:33.740 --> 00:04:37.640
we can get more of an idea of what
the infrastructure is behind the scenes.

79
00:04:37.640 --> 00:04:41.210
Now I've got a diagram up and
we've got some of the basic components.

80
00:04:41.210 --> 00:04:43.830
And then we'll talk about some of
the roles that these devices perform.

81
00:04:43.830 --> 00:04:47.540
So you'll see, just like Dan mentioned
we've got a series of servers.

82
00:04:47.540 --> 00:04:53.370
How you set this up is really
contingent on what kind of environment,

83
00:04:53.370 --> 00:04:56.500
but we are going to have
typically three servers.

84
00:04:56.500 --> 00:04:57.690
In this case for

85
00:04:57.690 --> 00:05:00.040
our demonstration purposes they
are going to be running server 2012R2.

86
00:05:00.040 --> 00:05:03.680
We've got some managed clients and these
are the clients that we are going to be

87
00:05:03.680 --> 00:05:08.530
managing things like their passwords,
their recovery keys as well.

88
00:05:08.530 --> 00:05:13.740
And then we've got a third,
if you will, type of device here, and

89
00:05:13.740 --> 00:05:18.650
this next one can be a client or
a server, it really doesn't matter.

90
00:05:18.650 --> 00:05:20.015
And let me show you what I mean by that.

91
00:05:20.015 --> 00:05:24.315
Because these servers that we have and

92
00:05:24.315 --> 00:05:27.855
the management workstation as
we see will come in handy.

93
00:05:27.855 --> 00:05:30.585
So one of the things that you need
as your domain controller, right?

94
00:05:30.585 --> 00:05:33.580
You have to have an active directory
domain, that's gonna be a prerequisite for

95
00:05:33.580 --> 00:05:34.790
using MBAM.

96
00:05:34.790 --> 00:05:37.300
The next thing that we're gonna
have is we're gonna have a couple

97
00:05:37.300 --> 00:05:40.060
other servers that are all
directly related to MBAM.

98
00:05:40.060 --> 00:05:43.500
And we have the Administration and
Monitoring Server.

99
00:05:43.500 --> 00:05:47.740
We also have a series of database servers,
and this is multiple databases, typically,

100
00:05:47.740 --> 00:05:49.110
running on a single server.

101
00:05:49.110 --> 00:05:52.110
And then we have this
management workstation.

102
00:05:52.110 --> 00:05:53.060
Now I do wanna mention,

103
00:05:53.060 --> 00:05:57.130
with a management work station, a doesn't
have to be a dedicated work station.

104
00:05:57.130 --> 00:06:01.590
Now you could, if you choose to,
make a dedicated work station, but

105
00:06:01.590 --> 00:06:03.010
you really don't need that.

106
00:06:03.010 --> 00:06:04.320
So let's go ahead, and

107
00:06:04.320 --> 00:06:08.330
one of the things that we should be doing
here is looking at the individual pieces.

108
00:06:08.330 --> 00:06:09.320
Now the domain controller,

109
00:06:09.320 --> 00:06:11.600
understand it's running
Active Directory Directory Services,

110
00:06:11.600 --> 00:06:13.420
it's your identity management solution.

111
00:06:13.420 --> 00:06:18.030
That's pretty obvious anytime you talk
about active directory, but what might not

112
00:06:18.030 --> 00:06:23.780
be so obvious is what are some of the
roles that these servers are performing.

113
00:06:23.780 --> 00:06:26.370
So let's go ahead and
let's look at the very first one.

114
00:06:26.370 --> 00:06:31.570
All right, the very first one is
the Administration and Monitoring Server.

115
00:06:31.570 --> 00:06:35.630
Now, this holds a couple of roles for
us that we'll use inside the MBAM.

116
00:06:35.630 --> 00:06:38.300
One of the things its gonna hold is
its gonna hold the Administration and

117
00:06:38.300 --> 00:06:39.850
Monitoring Website.

118
00:06:39.850 --> 00:06:43.440
Now, with the Administration Monitoring
Website keep in mind that what this is

119
00:06:43.440 --> 00:06:44.680
gonna be used for

120
00:06:44.680 --> 00:06:49.310
is to help users regain access to their
computers when they're locked out.

121
00:06:49.310 --> 00:06:50.820
Now that's the user portion of this.

122
00:06:50.820 --> 00:06:54.810
What does it help as far as
administration and monitoring website, for

123
00:06:54.810 --> 00:06:57.910
our administrators, the people that
are going to be supporting the users?

124
00:06:57.910 --> 00:07:01.130
Well, this is where they
can view the reports.

125
00:07:01.130 --> 00:07:05.400
They can view and display things like
compliance status, recovery activity for

126
00:07:05.400 --> 00:07:06.420
the different clients.

127
00:07:06.420 --> 00:07:11.930
So, maybe you wanna find out have there
been any recovery requests as it is.

128
00:07:11.930 --> 00:07:16.850
Somebody loses access to their
BitLocker encrypted drive, well,

129
00:07:16.850 --> 00:07:18.840
they're gonna have to submit a request for
recovery, and

130
00:07:18.840 --> 00:07:21.560
they're gonna have to give a reason and
then you're gonna have to approve it.

131
00:07:21.560 --> 00:07:26.540
So one of the other handy things with the
administration and monitoring website is,

132
00:07:26.540 --> 00:07:32.129
giving the administrators the ability
to implement things like recovery.

133
00:07:33.440 --> 00:07:36.790
Now the next thing that we have
here is the self service portal.

134
00:07:36.790 --> 00:07:40.910
Now with the self service portal, one of
the things we need to keep in mind is,

135
00:07:40.910 --> 00:07:46.400
if you set this up, this gives your users
a point of access that like it says,

136
00:07:46.400 --> 00:07:48.940
self service portal,
they can connect to a website.

137
00:07:48.940 --> 00:07:51.150
Remember I was telling you
that they have to file for

138
00:07:51.150 --> 00:07:55.140
a request to gain recovery
access back into their drive.

139
00:07:55.140 --> 00:07:57.250
Well, a self-service portal is
where they're gonna do that.

140
00:07:57.250 --> 00:08:00.541
They're going to go to that website and
if they have been locked out,

141
00:08:00.541 --> 00:08:03.324
they're gonna submit a request
that's gonna make its way

142
00:08:03.324 --> 00:08:06.584
into the administration and
monitoring website so that when your.

143
00:08:06.584 --> 00:08:10.734
Users, not your users, excuse me,
your administrators, your help desk staff,

144
00:08:10.734 --> 00:08:15.005
when they login to the website and they go
to the recovery section, they're gonna see

145
00:08:15.005 --> 00:08:18.560
that a request has been pending and
you can either approve or deny it.

146
00:08:18.560 --> 00:08:20.980
So administration and

147
00:08:20.980 --> 00:08:25.490
monitoring server, again keep in mind
does run on a Window's server box.

148
00:08:26.640 --> 00:08:30.040
All right,
now how about the database servers?

149
00:08:30.040 --> 00:08:33.160
Now when we look at the database servers,
keep in mind that there are multiple

150
00:08:33.160 --> 00:08:35.070
databases that are gonna
be running on this server.

151
00:08:36.990 --> 00:08:41.940
For our demonstration purposes,
we're gonna be using Microsoft SQL 2014.

152
00:08:41.940 --> 00:08:46.770
We will put in our show notes so you can
gain some more information on what's

153
00:08:46.770 --> 00:08:51.030
SQL editions are supported for MBAM.

154
00:08:51.030 --> 00:08:54.478
Cuz there are some different ones, and

155

374
00:21:52.100 --> 00:21:54.680
At the very minimum they're
gonna need the recovery ID

375
00:21:54.680 --> 00:21:59.080
that shows up on the computer's interface
when it goes into recovery mode.

376
00:21:59.080 --> 00:22:03.330
We've lost our BitLocker password,
we don't know what it is so

377
00:22:03.330 --> 00:22:05.280
we can enter in to recovery mode.

378
00:22:05.280 --> 00:22:09.600
We enter into recovery mode, there is
an identifier that is on that screen.

379
00:22:09.600 --> 00:22:15.690
Well that identifier has to be used and
has to be submitted to the administrator,

380
00:22:15.690 --> 00:22:19.640
so they first of all know
what BitLocker drive it is.

381
00:22:19.640 --> 00:22:21.620
The other thing we need
is a computer name.

382
00:22:21.620 --> 00:22:25.790
The computer name,
if you, one of the roles,

383
00:22:25.790 --> 00:22:29.900
one of the lesser roles I guess you would
say, if you're help desk and not advanced

384
00:22:29.900 --> 00:22:32.530
help desk is that they'd have to go
a little bit farther in their day, and

385
00:22:32.530 --> 00:22:37.710
they'd also have to put the user domain,
the computer name, and the recovery ID.

386
00:22:37.710 --> 00:22:42.280
If you're advanced help desk,
then you pretty much got all access, and

387
00:22:42.280 --> 00:22:44.170
all you really need is a recovery ID.

388
00:22:44.170 --> 00:22:48.170
And at that point, we can submit
the recovery ID, we can give them that

389
00:22:48.170 --> 00:22:51.820
information, and we can basically
give them the recovery password.

390
00:22:51.820 --> 00:22:56.400
They can enter it in, once they enter
that in they can unlock drive and

391
00:22:56.400 --> 00:22:58.740
then from there they can reset
their BitLocker password.

392
00:22:58.740 --> 00:23:02.110
And it's you know kind of like
resetting your username's password,

393
00:23:02.110 --> 00:23:05.200
if you needed to change your password
on your local computer there.

394
00:23:05.200 --> 00:23:05.800
>> Thanks.

395
00:23:05.800 --> 00:23:07.200
Well obviously there's
a lot of components,

396
00:23:07.200 --> 00:23:09.180
a lot of things that we
need to get down and

397
00:23:09.180 --> 00:23:14.440
dirty with when it comes to the Microsoft
desktop optimization pack itself And

398
00:23:14.440 --> 00:23:17.020
working with BitLocker is
always a grand old time.

399
00:23:17.020 --> 00:23:19.560
So we look forward to seeing you guys
in the upcoming episodes, but as for

400
00:23:19.560 --> 00:23:23.860
this one, Wes it looks like we have
covered all of our foundational bases, so

401
00:23:23.860 --> 00:23:25.840
we're going to call it a wrap for
todays show.

402
00:23:25.840 --> 00:23:28.010
Thanks for dropping by Wes,
thanks for explaining for

403
00:23:28.010 --> 00:23:29.760
us, and we thank you guys for watching.

404
00:23:29.760 --> 00:23:32.420
Signing off for IT PRO TV,
I've been your host Daniel Lawry.

405
00:23:32.420 --> 00:23:33.350
>> And I'm Wes Bryan.

406
00:23:33.350 --> 00:23:34.574
>> We'll see you next time.

407
00:23:34.574 --> 00:23:42.340
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Wes explain the preplanning steps necessary for the Microsoft Active Directory to work with Bitlocker Administration and Monitoring services. They will look at the user accounts and group roles used to manage the MBAM system. Finally they discuss the Group Policy templates that are downloaded and added for MBAM.
episodes.title: Preparing ADDS for MBAM
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.075 --> 00:00:16.377
All right greetings everyone and
welcome to another episode of ITPRO.TV.

3
00:00:16.377 --> 00:00:20.586
I'm your host Daniel Lowrie and in today's
episode we are continuing with our series

4
00:00:20.586 --> 00:00:24.562
on the Microsoft Desktop Optimization
Pack, and joining us back in the studio to

5
00:00:24.562 --> 00:00:27.280
help us out with that is our
good friend Mr. Wes Bryan.

6
00:00:27.280 --> 00:00:29.355
Wes, welcome back to the show sir,
how's it going today?

7
00:00:29.355 --> 00:00:31.179
>> Thanks for having me here,
I'll tell you Dan,

8
00:00:31.179 --> 00:00:33.196
that's one that I don't
mind using an acronym for.

9
00:00:33.196 --> 00:00:33.800
>> Yeah.
>> It's a-

10
00:00:33.800 --> 00:00:34.420
>> No doubt.

11
00:00:34.420 --> 00:00:36.570
>> It's like the song that never ends

12
00:00:36.570 --> 00:00:37.825
there.
But that's right,

13
00:00:37.825 --> 00:00:40.990
we're back with some MDOP, and
we're continuing along and

14
00:00:40.990 --> 00:00:43.350
here comes another acronym, MBAM.
We're

15
00:00:43.350 --> 00:00:46.960
talking about the Microsoft BitLocker
Administration and Monitoring.

16
00:00:46.960 --> 00:00:50.430
And one of the things that
we're going to go into today

17
00:00:50.430 --> 00:00:53.710
is preparing your Active Directory
infrastructure to get it ready so

18
00:00:53.710 --> 00:00:57.150
that it'll support MBAM when
you decide to deploy it.

19
00:00:57.150 --> 00:01:01.517
Now, there are some things that you
have to consider cuz there are a few

20
00:01:01.517 --> 00:01:05.603
different roles that we need to set up,
and users versus groups.

21
00:01:05.603 --> 00:01:09.735
And we kind of want to show you guys the
different user groups/roles that you're

22
00:01:09.735 --> 00:01:11.754
gonna see that need to be implemented.

23
00:01:11.754 --> 00:01:14.974
So if you're in a certification
endeavor and they ask you about MBAM,

24
00:01:14.974 --> 00:01:18.903
well you'll be able to knock it out of the
ballpark, if maybe you're just planning on

25
00:01:18.903 --> 00:01:21.870
testing this, maybe you do want
to roll this out to production.

26
00:01:21.870 --> 00:01:24.680
Well, it's still gonna be, either way,
you're still gonna have to

27
00:01:24.680 --> 00:01:29.255
know what are the roles and what are
the groups that we have inside of MBAM?

28
00:01:29.255 --> 00:01:32.672
>> Wes, we're still actually, still in
kind of the pre-stages as well, right?

29
00:01:32.672 --> 00:01:33.480
>> That's right,

30
00:01:33.480 --> 00:01:37.445
it's funny because at this point we
haven't deployed anything from MBAM.

31
00:01:37.445 --> 00:01:41.520
We've just been talking about it,
and that's why it is good planning.

32
00:01:41.520 --> 00:01:42.610
I'm glad you mentioned that Dan.

33
00:01:42.610 --> 00:01:46.702
Planning is everything, and
we're really in the planning phase here.

34
00:01:46.702 --> 00:01:48.619
And this should help you out and

35
00:01:48.619 --> 00:01:53.213
give you a good Idea of what you have
to set up prior to even deploying MBAM.

36
00:01:53.213 --> 00:01:56.215
Remember in a previous episode we
talked about the MBAM components.

37
00:01:56.215 --> 00:01:58.195
You need to know those components.

38
00:01:58.195 --> 00:02:00.975
You need to know what
operating systems you need.

39
00:02:00.975 --> 00:02:05.500
What server roles that you're gonna
provision in order to support MBAM.

40
00:02:05.500 --> 00:02:09.950
So a lot of setup beforehand, but once you
know the steps, you know what you have to

41
00:02:09.950 --> 00:02:13.740
setup, it will hopefully make you,
and that's at least the goal here.

42
00:02:13.740 --> 00:02:17.040
Is to make your deployment
of MBAM a little bit easier,

43
00:02:17.040 --> 00:02:20.960
go a little bit smoother than, obviously,
your end certification endeavor there.

44
00:02:20.960 --> 00:02:24.010
You'll be able to answer those questions
and get them right on the exam, too.

45
00:02:24.010 --> 00:02:25.480
So let's go ahead and

46
00:02:25.480 --> 00:02:28.930
we'll jump right into some of
the roles that we have inside of MBAM.

47
00:02:28.930 --> 00:02:33.285
Now, I do want you to keep in mind that
some of these roles can be combined.

48
00:02:33.285 --> 00:02:35.805
We're gonna go ahead and
mention the roles.

49
00:02:35.805 --> 00:02:36.925
And then we're gonna set them up.

50
00:02:36.925 --> 00:02:38.275
We're gonna show you how to set them up.

51
00:02:38.275 --> 00:02:41.715
So keep in mind that in some aspects here,

52
00:02:41.715 --> 00:02:44.800
some of these roles could be combined
into a single user or group.

53
00:02:44.800 --> 00:02:49.830
One of the first things that we have to
think about is our administration and

54
00:02:49.830 --> 00:02:51.110
monitoring website.

55
00:02:51.110 --> 00:02:53.220
Now what is this website gonna be for?

56
00:02:53.220 --> 00:02:57.900
Let's keep in mind that this is gonna be
where your Helpdesk Users are going to,

57
00:02:57.900 --> 00:03:01.930
well, help their end users
either recover their drives,

58
00:03:01.930 --> 00:03:04.700
manage and maintain things
like trusted platform modules,

59
00:03:04.700 --> 00:03:10.170
the TPMs, and
even see compliance information as well.

60
00:03:10.170 --> 00:03:14.240
Now when it comes to the users,
we've got two different roles here.

61
00:03:14.240 --> 00:03:19.020
We've got Helpdesk and we also have
what's known as Advanced Helpdesk.

62
00:03:19.020 --> 00:03:25.390
Now when we look at the roles, Helpdesk
specifically, these roles, you will see,

63
00:03:25.390 --> 00:03:30.640
provide the ability to manage the TPMs and
also manage drive recovery.

64
00:03:30.640 --> 00:03:34.230
Now, the other role that we have
is the Advanced Helpdesk User.

65
00:03:34.230 --> 00:03:35.850
Now, you might ask yourself,
well wait a second, Wes.

66
00:03:35.850 --> 00:03:40.870
What's the difference between a Helpdesk
and an Advanced Helpdesk User?

67
00:03:40.870 --> 00:03:42.160
Maybe a little bit more flare.

68
00:03:42.160 --> 00:03:46.070
But under the hood what's gonna happen is
the fact that the Advanced Helpdesk Users,

69
00:03:46.070 --> 00:03:48.820
they have all access, right.

70
00:03:48.820 --> 00:03:52.150
So, if you've ever been to a concert and
you see somebody with the all access pass,

71
00:03:52.150 --> 00:03:53.510
you're like, man I wish I had that.

72
00:03:53.510 --> 00:03:57.340
Well, that's essentially what your
Advanced HelpDesk Users are gonna have.

73
00:03:57.340 --> 00:04:01.460
Their gonna have all access to the
administration and monitoring websites.

74
00:04:01.460 --> 00:04:05.030
You might ask yourself, well wait a
second, well what's really the difference?

75
00:04:05.030 --> 00:04:09.330
Some of the differences are on how
they recover drives, if you will.

76
00:04:09.330 --> 00:04:12.550
So for instance,
if you're in a Helpdesk position, and

77
00:04:12.550 --> 00:04:17.315
you go to recover somebody's drive that's
been encrypted and then managed through

78
00:04:17.315 --> 00:04:21.295
your Microsoft BitLocker Administration
and Monitoring platform.

79
00:04:21.295 --> 00:04:25.690
Then the Helpdesk, all they can do is
manage the TPMs and the drive recovery.

80
00:04:25.690 --> 00:04:28.380
And more importantly,
when it comes to drive recovery,

81
00:04:28.380 --> 00:04:30.518
they've got to enter
a little bit more data.

82
00:04:30.518 --> 00:04:35.291
In the previous episode one of the things
that Dan had asked is the information

83
00:04:35.291 --> 00:04:39.340
that we have to provide,
is this an automated approach, right?

84
00:04:39.340 --> 00:04:42.290
Does a user,
they forget their BitLocker password.

85
00:04:42.290 --> 00:04:45.240
Can they just fill out a form,
automatically get sent up, and

86
00:04:45.240 --> 00:04:48.930
we click some kind of button and
they're recovered.

87
00:04:48.930 --> 00:04:50.260
Well, there again,

88
00:04:50.260 --> 00:04:53.390
it's really contingent on these two
roles on how that's gonna be done.

89
00:04:53.390 --> 00:04:57.420
So if you're a Helpdesk User, you gotta
enter a little bit more information before

90
00:04:57.420 --> 00:04:58.470
you can do drive recovery.

91
00:04:58.470 --> 00:05:04.070
You gotta enter the computer name and the
user's domain name, or domain in general.

92
00:05:04.070 --> 00:05:06.660
And then also a recovery identifier.

93
00:05:06.660 --> 00:05:10.764
Now the recovery identifier,
if you're not familiar with what that is,

94
00:05:10.764 --> 00:05:13.093
that's associated with a recovery key.

95
00:05:13.093 --> 00:05:20.178
The recovery key is a 48 digit key,
kind of like activation is in software,

96
00:05:20.178 --> 00:05:25.958
that is going to be tied to
a specific encryption of BitLocker.

97
00:05:25.958 --> 00:05:30.650
Associated with the recovery
key is a drive identifier.

98
00:05:30.650 --> 00:05:33.230
It's a little key ID that says, okay,

99
00:05:33.230 --> 00:05:38.850
this ID is associated with this drive and
this 48 digit recovery key.

100
00:05:38.850 --> 00:05:42.840
If you're in the Helpdesk group then you
have to put in again the computer name,

101
00:05:42.840 --> 00:05:46.250
the user's domain and that recovery ID.

102
00:05:46.250 --> 00:05:51.240
Now Advanced Helpdesk Users not
only have a complete access

103
00:05:51.240 --> 00:05:54.440
to the administration and
monitoring website,

104
00:05:54.440 --> 00:06:00.710
they don't have to put in the user
domain and the computer name.

105
00:06:00.710 --> 00:06:03.370
All they have to know is the recovery ID,
so

106
00:06:03.370 --> 00:06:09.110
this might be something where maybe your
Helpdesk is trying to recover a drive and

107
00:06:09.110 --> 00:06:13.090
the user says, well I'm not
really sure what my domain is.

108
00:06:13.090 --> 00:06:14.370
We'll just give you a scenario here.

109
00:06:14.370 --> 00:06:17.800
What if scenario, where maybe they don't
know not only what the user name is,

110
00:06:17.800 --> 00:06:19.700
maybe they don't know what
their computer name is.

111
00:06:19.700 --> 00:06:22.600
Well if you don't have that information
then this might be something

112
00:06:22.600 --> 00:06:24.060
that you perform escalation.

113
00:06:24.060 --> 00:06:28.042
If I don't have the privileges,
permissions or know how to help an end

114
00:06:28.042 --> 00:06:31.622
user then I'm gonna have to
escalate it somebody higher tier,

115
00:06:31.622 --> 00:06:35.625
level tier that does know how to or
has the privileges to perform that.

116
00:06:35.625 --> 00:06:38.724
And that's where the Advanced Helpdesk
comes in, because if they

117
00:06:38.724 --> 00:06:42.373
don't have a user's domain, they don't
have the computer ID, then they get

118
00:06:42.373 --> 00:06:45.890
the ability to just put in the recovery
information, and they're good.

119
00:06:45.890 --> 00:06:49.640
Now you might say, well wait a second,
where do we get the recovery IDs?

120
00:06:49.640 --> 00:06:52.710
Well we'll show you when we do a recovery
later on, but let's just go ahead and

121
00:06:52.710 --> 00:06:53.560
generically set the stage.

122
00:06:53.560 --> 00:06:57.042
And allow that the recovery ID,
when you forget a BitLocker password, or

123
00:06:57.042 --> 00:06:59.700
maybe you enter wrong and
it enters into recovery mode.

124
00:06:59.700 --> 00:07:04.411
Right there on the computer screen will
be that ID that the end user's gonna have

125
00:07:04.411 --> 00:07:09.380
to report to whoever the Helpdesk user
is in order for them to enter it.

126
00:07:09.380 --> 00:07:11.130
Now I do want to make one mention.

127
00:07:11.130 --> 00:07:13.040
And they mention this out in TechNet, and

128
00:07:13.040 --> 00:07:17.680
like I said, we're gonna litter you guys
with a whole bunch of show notes here and

129
00:07:17.680 --> 00:07:21.780
some URL so that you can go and research
this information more on your own.

130
00:07:21.780 --> 00:07:25.320
If you wanna get even more
information about some of the roles.

131
00:07:25.320 --> 00:07:30.090
But, one of the things they
point out here is that,

132
00:07:30.090 --> 00:07:33.020
my head's kind of covering it up here.

133
00:07:33.020 --> 00:07:37.120
If the user is a part of both
of these groups, all right?

134
00:07:37.120 --> 00:07:40.020
So let's say Dan comes in,
Dan's part of the Helpdesk.

135
00:07:40.020 --> 00:07:44.530
Dan says all of the sudden, hey I need
to gain access to that recovery console.

136
00:07:44.530 --> 00:07:45.810
And we don't have that information.

137
00:07:45.810 --> 00:07:46.809
So I say okay, you know what Dan?

138
00:07:46.809 --> 00:07:49.549
Let's make you an Advanced Helpdesk User.

139
00:07:49.549 --> 00:07:53.300
Well now those permissions
are gonna override the Helpdesk.

140
00:07:53.300 --> 00:07:56.537
So If you have one user in both groups,
be careful with this,

141
00:07:56.537 --> 00:08:00.960
remember we're talking about security,
that's what BitLocker's all about.

142
00:08:00.960 --> 00:08:04.782
And if you are looking for principle of
least privilege and you give somebody

143
00:08:04.782 --> 00:08:08.498
access to both user groups,
then the Advanced HelpDesk will overwrite.

144
00:08:08.498 --> 00:08:13.496
So potentially, you could be giving
somebody more access than exactly

145
00:08:13.496 --> 00:08:16.470
what they need, so do keep that in mind.

146
00:08:16.470 --> 00:08:21.000
So Dan, when it comes to the Helpdesk,
and you know what I didn't mention is,

147
00:08:21.000 --> 00:08:25.420
the users here, they can be a group or
it could be a specific user.

148
00:08:25.420 --> 00:08:28.858
Now we talk about
role-based access control.

149
00:08:28.858 --> 00:08:32.649
And I really would agree that this is
the way that we should be doing that,

150
00:08:32.649 --> 00:08:34.710
rather than just having a single user.

151
00:08:34.710 --> 00:08:37.181
Cuz if you're in a large
Enterprise environment,

152
00:08:37.181 --> 00:08:40.869
you're probably not just going to have
a single user for Helpdesk, right?

153
00:08:40.869 --> 00:08:44.851
So I would recommend that if you're gonna
set this up, even though the documentation

154
00:08:44.851 --> 00:08:48.020
says it could be a user or group,
I would make these groups for both.

155
00:08:48.020 --> 00:08:51.132
Because then in Active Directory,
when go to provision your users,

156
00:08:51.132 --> 00:08:52.214
then you create a user.

157
00:08:52.214 --> 00:08:54.163
Or as you hire onboard new staff,

158
00:08:54.163 --> 00:08:58.838
you can drop them right into the Advanced
Helpdesk group or the Helpdesk group.

159
00:08:58.838 --> 00:09:03.521
And in the background, one of
the great things about the MBAM setup,

160
00:09:03.521 --> 00:09:05.640
is it manages the privileges.

161
00:09:05.640 --> 00:09:09.225
When it goes through and it installs,
it provisions in Active Directory

162
00:09:09.225 --> 00:09:12.869
the appropriate permissions for
the roles that these groups provide, or

163
00:09:12.869 --> 00:09:15.240
the functionality that
these groups provide.

164
00:09:15.240 --> 00:09:19.170
And that's why I would say, don't limit
yourself to just user or a group.

165
00:09:19.170 --> 00:09:22.620
Now, in demonstration purposes you might
see that I will not be practicing what I

166
00:09:22.620 --> 00:09:23.240
preach in here.

167
00:09:23.240 --> 00:09:25.320
Just for the demonstration purposes.

168
00:09:25.320 --> 00:09:28.310
But definitely in your Active Directory
you wanna be careful on how you do this.

169
00:09:28.310 --> 00:09:31.149
And you don't wanna tie this or
associate it with just a single

170
00:09:31.149 --> 00:09:34.200
end user because well,
that can always cause problems here.

171
00:09:34.200 --> 00:09:37.100
>> And Wes, you were saying, just to
make sure and clarify, and I thought,

172
00:09:37.100 --> 00:09:38.450
I understand.

173
00:09:38.450 --> 00:09:42.520
Is that when we're talking about
the access privileges when it comes to

174
00:09:42.520 --> 00:09:47.310
either the user or group that we create
for this, is that it is aggregate.

175
00:09:47.310 --> 00:09:51.343
It is not, I've got two sets of,
if I'm in both groups and

176
00:09:51.343 --> 00:09:56.004
I've got two sets of permissions,
the least amount of privilege wins.

177
00:09:56.004 --> 00:10:00.500
It's they aggregate together, and then
that becomes how much privilege I have.

178
00:10:00.500 --> 00:10:03.600
>> That's a very good question there and
that is right.

179
00:10:03.600 --> 00:10:06.340
When we talk about things like
permissions and sharing permissions,

180
00:10:06.340 --> 00:10:09.460
combined with MTFS permissions,
in some of our other episodes,

181
00:10:09.460 --> 00:10:12.010
right, we know that it's the most
restrictive that wins out.

182
00:10:12.010 --> 00:10:15.150
So if somebody's got read and they've
got full control and we're talking about

183
00:10:15.150 --> 00:10:19.270
comparing NTFS to shared permissions,
right, the most restrictive comes out.

184
00:10:19.270 --> 00:10:21.960

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Wes take you through the installation of the MBAM utility. They begin by explaining the prerequisites that will need to be installed before the MBAM installation can begin. This includes IIS web server service as well as SQL server and ASP .NET frameworks. Finally they are able to walk you through each step to getting MBAM installed.

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Wes show you how to deploy and configure MBAM. They start by getting the client installed on a desktop workstation running Windows 10. Then they go back to the server and configure all the necessary settings through Group Policy. They also walk you through all the GPO settings for MBAM, explaining them as they go.
episodes.title: Deploying and Configuring MBAM

All right, so restarting pending here.

644
00:35:24.870 --> 00:35:29.330
And we're gonna use our manage-bde

645
00:35:29.330 --> 00:35:33.570
command because it's a very
good command that gives

646
00:35:33.570 --> 00:35:36.710
you the command prompt to kinda see
what's going on in the background.

647
00:35:36.710 --> 00:35:40.530
So here's our BitLocker password,
or I should say interface,

648
00:35:40.530 --> 00:35:42.440
where we've got to enter the password.

649
00:35:42.440 --> 00:35:45.123
Keep in mind,
all that does is unlocks the drive.

650
00:35:45.123 --> 00:35:46.820
I still have to log in, right?

651
00:35:46.820 --> 00:35:49.800
That does not log me into the computer.

652
00:35:49.800 --> 00:35:51.440
Bitlocker says, okay.

653
00:35:51.440 --> 00:35:55.120
Now the operating system's allowed to run,
you're going to get a login screen,

654
00:35:55.120 --> 00:35:56.530
now you can log in.

655
00:35:56.530 --> 00:35:59.860
So, we'll try to type that
super secret password again.

656
00:35:59.860 --> 00:36:01.670
And we get logged into this.

657
00:36:01.670 --> 00:36:05.660
One of the last things I wanna do in this
episode is fire up the command prompt,

658
00:36:05.660 --> 00:36:07.390
show you the manage-bde command, and

659
00:36:07.390 --> 00:36:10.640
the fact that this machine
is now being encrypted.

660
00:36:10.640 --> 00:36:15.370
And it is good to know the manage-bde

661
00:36:15.370 --> 00:36:19.690
command anyways when it comes to managing
your BitLocker drive encryptions.

662
00:36:19.690 --> 00:36:25.306
Please keep in mind that this does require
an administrative level command prompt.

663
00:36:25.306 --> 00:36:27.080
All right, and
give me a second here, guys.

664
00:36:27.080 --> 00:36:30.020
We'll make this just a little bit
easier for you to see out there.

665
00:36:33.345 --> 00:36:35.105
I'll go all Matrix on it again.

666
00:36:35.105 --> 00:36:41.950
And we're gonna type manage-bde,

667
00:36:41.950 --> 00:36:47.280
space, and then -status.

668
00:36:47.280 --> 00:36:52.900
All right, and then it looks like this
machine is already 64% encrypted.

669
00:36:52.900 --> 00:36:57.980
We left the encryption the way,
the defaults, we didn't do 256.

670
00:36:57.980 --> 00:37:00.366
We can see the Key Protectors.

671
00:37:00.366 --> 00:37:01.369
What are the Key Protectors?

672
00:37:01.369 --> 00:37:02.548
Are we allowing pins?

673
00:37:02.548 --> 00:37:04.100
Are we allowing TPMs?

674
00:37:04.100 --> 00:37:06.262
Are we allowing passwords?

675
00:37:06.262 --> 00:37:10.227
So we can see that the password, or
the Key Protectors, as they call it,

676
00:37:10.227 --> 00:37:13.542
how are we protected the BitLocker
key is through a numerical

677
00:37:13.542 --> 00:37:17.850
password that we've set and
defined beforehand in the group policy.

678
00:37:17.850 --> 00:37:22.580
And we're now managing out client through
the Microsoft BitLocker Administration and

679
00:37:22.580 --> 00:37:24.350
Monitoring software.

680
00:37:24.350 --> 00:37:27.606
>> Awesome stuff, Wes, and really actually
didn't seem to be that difficult.

681
00:37:27.606 --> 00:37:31.106
I mean, we did all the hard work
back in our previous episodes,

682
00:37:31.106 --> 00:37:35.090
now it's just basically reaping
the benefits of that hard labor.

683
00:37:35.090 --> 00:37:41.010
We're installing the client into
the actual client was relatively simple,

684
00:37:41.010 --> 00:37:44.090
and any of the things that
might seem confusing,

685
00:37:44.090 --> 00:37:46.490
well you walked us through
those conundrums as well.

686
00:37:46.490 --> 00:37:48.830
So we appreciate those clarifications.

687
00:37:48.830 --> 00:37:49.600
That being said,

688
00:37:49.600 --> 00:37:53.410
looks like we have run out of time,
but we have a configured system.

689
00:37:53.410 --> 00:37:57.080
We're looking forward to getting into more
of the meat and potatoes of that system.

690
00:37:57.080 --> 00:38:00.980
But we're outta time for this episode,
so that'll have to be in the future.

691
00:38:00.980 --> 00:38:03.550
That being said, we're gonna go ahead and
sign off for ITPro TV.

692
00:38:03.550 --> 00:38:05.580
I've been your host Daniel Lowry.

693
00:38:05.580 --> 00:38:06.590
>> And I'm Wes Bryan.

694
00:38:06.590 --> 00:38:08.723
>> See you next time.

695
00:38:08.723 --> 00:38:16.450
[MUSIC].

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Wes explore the actual administration and recovery of end devices using the MBAM administration console. They start by looking at the End User experience. Then they look at the Compliance and Auditing features. Finally, they demonstrate and actual recovery of a client machine.
episodes.title: Administering and Recovery
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:11.954 --> 00:00:16.808
All right, greetings everyone, and welcome
to another great episode of ITPro.TV.

3
00:00:16.808 --> 00:00:21.031
I'm your host Daniel Lowrie, and
in today's episode we're continuing on

4
00:00:21.031 --> 00:00:25.061
with our series Looking at the Microsoft
desktop, wait not operating.

5
00:00:25.061 --> 00:00:26.021
The optimization.

6
00:00:26.021 --> 00:00:28.830
I get the desktop
operating stuck in my head.

7
00:00:28.830 --> 00:00:29.730
Optimization pack.

8
00:00:29.730 --> 00:00:31.210
That's what we're looking at today.

9
00:00:31.210 --> 00:00:35.750
Joining us in the studio to lend
his expertise on that topic,

10
00:00:35.750 --> 00:00:37.150
our good friend Mr. Wes Bryan.

11
00:00:37.150 --> 00:00:38.140
Wes, welcome to the show sir.

12
00:00:38.140 --> 00:00:39.380
How's it going?
>> It's going great.

13
00:00:39.380 --> 00:00:41.110
And as always, it's good to be here.

14
00:00:41.110 --> 00:00:42.270
That's right, MDOP.

15
00:00:42.270 --> 00:00:46.360
I tell you what, they don't shy away
from their acronyms when it comes to

16
00:00:46.360 --> 00:00:47.940
any kind of desktop support.

17
00:00:47.940 --> 00:00:53.560
So we're coming back at you again with
more of the Microsoft BitLocker and

18
00:00:53.560 --> 00:00:55.180
administration and management.

19
00:00:55.180 --> 00:00:56.100
>> Not so easy is it.

20
00:00:56.100 --> 00:00:57.370
>> Apparantely I can't say it.

21
00:00:57.370 --> 00:00:58.160
Let's try that again.

22
00:00:58.160 --> 00:00:59.510
So stepping back from that.

23
00:00:59.510 --> 00:01:03.460
The Microsoft Bitlocker administration and
monitoring software.

24
00:01:03.460 --> 00:01:07.270
And in the first few episodes
we've shown you prerequisites and

25
00:01:07.270 --> 00:01:11.590
how to get it set up and how to configure
some of the settings in group policy,

26
00:01:11.590 --> 00:01:15.320
preparing Active Directory as well
as deploying the client out and

27
00:01:15.320 --> 00:01:19.260
then showing you some of the settings that
you could configure through our group

28
00:01:19.260 --> 00:01:20.540
policy management console.

29
00:01:20.540 --> 00:01:25.270
But now it's time to do a little
bit of administration, if you will.

30
00:01:25.270 --> 00:01:28.310
So we're gonna look at some of the
websites that we've talked about as well

31
00:01:28.310 --> 00:01:32.020
as what can your end users expect to see?

32
00:01:32.020 --> 00:01:34.420
And that's something good to know
because if you're gonna troubleshoot it,

33
00:01:34.420 --> 00:01:37.430
you really have to be able to see
what the end users are seeing.

34
00:01:37.430 --> 00:01:39.130
So that's where we're going to start.

35
00:01:39.130 --> 00:01:41.960
First thing we're gonna do here, we'll
kick it off with a little bit of a client

36
00:01:41.960 --> 00:01:44.480
experience and
what they can expect to see.

37
00:01:44.480 --> 00:01:46.620
So I've got a Windows machine up here,

38
00:01:46.620 --> 00:01:49.350
and in one of the previous
episodes that Dan and

39
00:01:49.350 --> 00:01:54.255
I did, you might remember that we talked
about putting in an enforcement policy.

40
00:01:54.255 --> 00:02:00.240
Taking a series of days and saying,
within this amount of time you have,

41
00:02:00.240 --> 00:02:04.210
you can postpone your encryption,
but after let's say the fourth day,

42
00:02:04.210 --> 00:02:08.040
you're gonna be required to encrypt,
and you can see that right here, and

43
00:02:08.040 --> 00:02:11.750
this is what they're gonna see
once group policy fires off.

44
00:02:11.750 --> 00:02:16.330
Your client machine
contacts Active Directory,

45
00:02:16.330 --> 00:02:19.200
looks at what the policy is and
then you turn around and

46
00:02:19.200 --> 00:02:22.810
you contact the reporting database
server in the background.

47
00:02:22.810 --> 00:02:24.510
And then it says you know what?

48
00:02:24.510 --> 00:02:28.252
You're reporting that you're not in
compliance right now because your drive

49
00:02:28.252 --> 00:02:32.160
isn't encrypted so
this screen does come up.

50
00:02:32.160 --> 00:02:35.180
And as you can see,
it gives us the option to postpone it.

51
00:02:35.180 --> 00:02:40.025
Remember one of the newer features
in MBAM 2.5 Service Pack One

52
00:02:40.025 --> 00:02:43.650
was the fact that we could
enforce it right away.

53
00:02:43.650 --> 00:02:46.225
We can say you we're not gonna
allow you to postpone it.

54
00:02:46.225 --> 00:02:47.935
The moment you see this,

55
00:02:47.935 --> 00:02:51.205
we're gonna only give you
the option to start the encryption.

56
00:02:51.205 --> 00:02:55.595
Now, it's a little bit different
on how we do the encryption versus

57
00:02:55.595 --> 00:02:58.872
maybe what you've traditionally
seen in the the control panel.

58
00:02:58.872 --> 00:03:02.292
And what I like about this is
they put that front and center.

59
00:03:02.292 --> 00:03:03.762
You cannot ignore it.

60
00:03:03.762 --> 00:03:05.842
If you see me grabbing
onto the control panel,

61
00:03:05.842 --> 00:03:07.772
that's still right there in the front.

62
00:03:07.772 --> 00:03:11.579
So they really do not want you,
there's no way to miss it,

63
00:03:11.579 --> 00:03:13.468
let's just put it that way.

64
00:03:13.468 --> 00:03:17.462
So let me kinda pull this to the side here
and show you maybe what you've already

65
00:03:17.462 --> 00:03:19.742
traditionally seen with
BitLocker encryption.

66
00:03:19.742 --> 00:03:22.380
We could turn our BitLocker
encryption on here.

67
00:03:22.380 --> 00:03:28.030
And a lot of us that maybe have studied
for some of the client exams in the past,

68
00:03:28.030 --> 00:03:32.140
you've probably seen this route
more than maybe you want to.

69
00:03:32.140 --> 00:03:36.260
But with the BitLocker encryption
options that we have here,

70
00:03:36.260 --> 00:03:40.740
remember that there is an additional
option that is controlling this down here.

71
00:03:40.740 --> 00:03:44.120
Because we do have the MBAM
client installed so

72
00:03:44.120 --> 00:03:49.190
the MBAM client is communicating with our
servers, our compliant servers, and then

73
00:03:49.190 --> 00:03:52.853
again with Active Directory to see where
the policies are, what the policies state.

74
00:03:52.853 --> 00:03:57.760
And in this case, our policy is
stating that we can postpone it for so

75
00:03:57.760 --> 00:03:59.540
many days, or we can start the encryption.

76
00:03:59.540 --> 00:04:01.455
But let's go ahead, and
we're gonna start the encryption.

77
00:04:01.455 --> 00:04:03.610
Now keep in mind guys,
we're not gonna wait for

78
00:04:03.610 --> 00:04:07.390
this thing to do a full encryption,
but we do want to show you

79
00:04:07.390 --> 00:04:10.740
what it looks like when the user
starts their encryption process.

80
00:04:10.740 --> 00:04:14.770
Now notice that the screen is a little
bit different, but Dan you can see,

81
00:04:14.770 --> 00:04:19.200
steps are really pretty much the same
as you would see on the interface.

82
00:04:19.200 --> 00:04:23.660
Now another way to understand that yes,
MBAM is controlling this,

83
00:04:23.660 --> 00:04:25.250
this is a virtual machine guys.

84
00:04:25.250 --> 00:04:27.860
So no TV magic or voodoo out there,

85
00:04:27.860 --> 00:04:29.690
this is a virtual machine
that we're controlling.

86
00:04:29.690 --> 00:04:32.180
And keep in mind that it
doesn't have the TPM.

87
00:04:32.180 --> 00:04:36.390
So remember if you don't have
a trusted platform module by

88
00:04:36.390 --> 00:04:39.490
default you can't use
BitLocker encryption without

89
00:04:39.490 --> 00:04:43.040
configuring a couple of group policies
that allow that option to be changed.

90
00:04:43.040 --> 00:04:49.870
But because we're managing it through
the MDOP MBAM portion of the GPO,

91
00:04:49.870 --> 00:04:53.880
that is gonna be completely ignored and
it's gonna let us know that if we want to

92
00:04:53.880 --> 00:04:58.510
allow non-TPM platforms to use BitLocker,
we could choose to do that.

93
00:04:58.510 --> 00:05:02.600
And that's what we've done here and that's
why it isn't throwing an error that says

94
00:05:02.600 --> 00:05:07.360
that you can't use it because no
trusted platform module has been found.

95
00:05:07.360 --> 00:05:10.500
Now we're gonna go ahead and
we'll enter our password here.

96
00:05:10.500 --> 00:05:12.730
And we'll go ahead and
create our password.

97
00:05:12.730 --> 00:05:16.770
Now the interesting thing that
I want you to keep in mind.

98
00:05:16.770 --> 00:05:20.970
When we go through the encryption
process in the traditional, and

99
00:05:20.970 --> 00:05:24.860
it looks like, so
hopefully I can pause on that.

100
00:05:24.860 --> 00:05:25.950
I didn't get to.

101
00:05:25.950 --> 00:05:30.600
But so when you encrypt through
the normal BitLocker interface,

102
00:05:30.600 --> 00:05:33.740
you might realize that you
have to set a recovery key,

103
00:05:33.740 --> 00:05:36.650
you've got to save it to a file,
to a different location.

104
00:05:36.650 --> 00:05:38.720
We've actually done that here
in some of the episodes, so

105
00:05:38.720 --> 00:05:41.250
if you haven't seen that go back and
watch some of those earlier episodes.

106
00:05:41.250 --> 00:05:46.080
So you might be asking yourself well,
why didn't it save the recovery key here?

107
00:05:46.080 --> 00:05:49.660
It didn't even ask me,
didn't give me the no,

108
00:05:49.660 --> 00:05:52.630
you can't save this on the same
drive that it's gonna be encrypted.

109
00:05:52.630 --> 00:05:55.560
All those good little warnings that you
get when you're setting up BitLocker.

110
00:05:55.560 --> 00:05:56.448
Well, why is that?

111
00:05:56.448 --> 00:06:02.240
Well, I want you to remember that, in some
of the settings that we've looked at,

112
00:06:02.240 --> 00:06:05.800
keep in mind that this isn't
being stored locally anymore.

113
00:06:05.800 --> 00:06:11.010
If you remember some of those registry
key settings that we were looking at,

114
00:06:11.010 --> 00:06:15.640
keep in mind that it's actually
being managed by MDOP.

115
00:06:15.640 --> 00:06:18.480
And if we look at some of those
registry settings in here,

116
00:06:18.480 --> 00:06:23.732
you'll remember that we set
up a recovery point service.

117
00:06:23.732 --> 00:06:28.040
So where the recover information
would get sent to a database, and

118
00:06:28.040 --> 00:06:29.240
you can see that right here.

119
00:06:29.240 --> 00:06:30.730
So that's one of the reasons, and

120
00:06:30.730 --> 00:06:35.370
what I mean more specifically by that is
notice the key recovery service endpoint.

121
00:06:35.370 --> 00:06:39.982
Well that's the actual service that's
gonna receive the recovery key and

122
00:06:39.982 --> 00:06:42.685
the way we set it up,
if you remember, Dan,

123
00:06:42.685 --> 00:06:45.630
was the fact that we did
the key package as well.

124
00:06:45.630 --> 00:06:47.260
We said we wanna save all of it.

125
00:06:47.260 --> 00:06:48.910
We don't wanna just save the recovery key.

126
00:06:48.910 --> 00:06:53.550
We'll save the BitLocker encryption key
in case we ever need to recover it and

127
00:06:53.550 --> 00:06:55.740
you can do that likewise.

128
00:06:55.740 --> 00:06:58.540
So that's one of the reasons
we aren't getting

129
00:06:58.540 --> 00:07:03.370
that warning about the recovery key
is because it's automated for us now.

130
00:07:03.370 --> 00:07:07.820
Remember with your end user experience,
the less they have to interact with it,

131
00:07:07.820 --> 00:07:10.620
the less they can be in control of it,
and really

132
00:07:10.620 --> 00:07:16.020
the less they see of a certain technology,
it just makes for a better experience.

133
00:07:16.020 --> 00:07:18.620
I don't need to worry about,
where did they save it?

134
00:07:18.620 --> 00:07:20.030
Did they save it to a thumb drive?

135
00:07:20.030 --> 00:07:21.710
Did they save it to the corporate shared?

136
00:07:21.710 --> 00:07:22.760
Did they save it locally?

137
00:07:22.760 --> 00:07:24.004
Where did they save it?

138
00:07:24.004 --> 00:07:27.140
In this aspect,
the client doesn't need to do any of that.

139
00:07:27.140 --> 00:07:29.730
They just, like you see,
they set the password and

140
00:07:29.730 --> 00:07:32.250
it starts the encryption process.

141
00:07:33.330 --> 00:07:37.840
That being said, the other thing
that it didn't require us to do, and

142
00:07:37.840 --> 00:07:41.892
maybe you might remember this as well,
Dan, is the fact that,

143
00:07:41.892 --> 00:07:46.495
when we set the BitLocker encryption
up without MBAM, what does it do?

144
00:07:46.495 --> 00:07:49.705
It requires us to run
a system integrity check and

145
00:07:49.705 --> 00:07:55.041
restart the computer before the BitLocker
encryption process will even start.

146
00:07:55.041 --> 00:07:58.830
But if I jump down to
a command prompt here, And

147
00:07:58.830 --> 00:08:04.090
I'll make this a little bit easier for
you guys to see out there.

148
00:08:04.090 --> 00:08:08.250
I know the gray's sometimes
a little bit hard to see.

149
00:08:08.250 --> 00:08:10.643
We'll change that up a little bit.

150
00:08:12.705 --> 00:08:14.540
Now we'll do eye piercing yellow.

151
00:08:14.540 --> 00:08:17.300
That looks like it didn't
change it too much.

152
00:08:17.300 --> 00:08:22.198
All right.
So if we run our manage-bde command

153
00:08:22.198 --> 00:08:27.110
with the option being-status here.

154
00:08:28.980 --> 00:08:33.770
And we give that a second to run and look
at the system, we're gonna find that yes,

155
00:08:33.770 --> 00:08:36.400
the bit locker encryption
process has been started.

156
00:08:36.400 --> 00:08:39.420
We've got to be in administrative level
command prompt, let's try that again.

157
00:08:42.819 --> 00:08:44.200
All right.

158
00:08:44.200 --> 00:08:47.180
And hopefully that will
get us started up there.

159
00:08:47.180 --> 00:08:48.560
There we go.
That's what we want.

160
00:08:48.560 --> 00:08:52.010
So, now if we try that.

161
00:08:52.010 --> 00:08:56.830
Image-bde, remember

162
00:08:56.830 --> 00:09:00.150
with the status parameter,
there we go that's what we want to see,

163
00:09:00.150 --> 00:09:05.020
notice we're already half way done with
the encryption process already and

164
00:09:05.020 --> 00:09:09.310
we didn't have to restart the machine
keep in mind that our key protectors,

165
00:09:09.310 --> 00:09:12.250
we can see that the password is there,
the numerical password.

166
00:09:12.250 --> 00:09:15.970
Remember your key protectors are how
are you protecting the bit locker

167
00:09:15.970 --> 00:09:17.050
drive in general.

168
00:09:17.050 --> 00:09:20.540
You might see a TPM in here if you
see a TPM a lot of times you'll see

169
00:09:20.540 --> 00:09:24.560
some of the things that we've
talked about in other episodes like

170
00:09:24.560 --> 00:09:27.500
the platform configuration registers.

171
00:09:27.500 --> 00:09:29.840
But for us, right here,
we're just using a password.

172
00:09:29.840 --> 00:09:33.270
So, pretty straight forward process here.

173
00:09:33.270 --> 00:09:35.240
Very transparent to the end-user.

174
00:09:35.240 --> 00:09:39.760
I say transparent,
transparent in the fact that there's

175

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Wes explore the handy tool from Microsoft known as the Diagnostic and Recovery Toolset. They start by explaining what the DaRT is and walk you through setting up the prerequisites for its installation. Then they demonstrate the install of the DaRT system.

Now it's going to have, well,

00:24:24.430 --> 00:24:28.120

00:24:28.120 --> 00:24:30.500
You got a blue screen,

00:24:30.500 --> 00:24:33.740
If you think about task scheduling,

00:24:33.740 --> 00:24:36.890
so a lot of good things that you
can do with Computer Management,

00:24:36.890 --> 00:24:38.440
you can see some of
the other options here.

We got Crash Analyzer,

00:24:41.040 --> 00:24:43.010
That one's a really cool utility.

00:24:43.010 --> 00:24:46.540

00:24:46.540 --> 00:24:50.500
Now with Disk Commander, this is

00:24:50.500 --> 00:24:51.720

00:24:55.120 --> 00:24:56.980

00:24:59.770 --> 00:25:00.700

00:25:01.740 --> 00:25:05.580
All right, so I'm gonna say let's go for

00:26:13.930 --> 00:26:15.700
So, I'm just gonna leave it.

I'm gonna let Windows choose

Whatever's relative to your environment,

Now here's another thing

If you know that for

Windows deployment service, you know

Well I want you to understand something.

You can take those driver packages and put

00:26:46.260 --> 00:26:51.620
so if you've got a network
adapter that is not recognized

00:26:51.620 --> 00:26:55.930
in the early boot process, the driver will
be included in dart, it'll load it up and

00:26:55.930 --> 00:26:58.670

00:26:58.670 --> 00:27:01.480
On that computer that I've got

If I would put the driver inside of Dart,

00:27:12.990 --> 00:27:15.840

00:27:15.840 --> 00:27:18.340
So pay attention to the drivers

If you need additional options

00:27:26.610 --> 00:27:28.690

well you know what, I've already

And then you'll see debuggers.

Notice that, and

All right,

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Wes continue their look at the Diagnostic and Recovery Toolset. In the previous episode they got it successfully installed, so here they show you how to create a DaRT image and use the DaRT system to remotely access a client PC. They also demonstrate all the tools that come bundled with DaRT.

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Wes explore application virtualization with Microsoft's AppV software. Here they explain the concept of application virtualization and the prerequisites for installing the AppV Sequencer. Then they sequence a software program for the purposes of virtualizing on a client computer.
episodes.title: Application Virtualization
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:11.878 --> 00:00:16.630
All right, greetings everyone, and welcome
to another great episode of ITProTV.

I'm your host Daniel Lowrie and in today's
episode we're continuing on with our

4

Microsoft Desktop
Optimization Pack Series.

Joining us back in the studio again to
lend his expertise on that very topic is

00:00:27.260 --> 00:00:29.470
our good friend and mentor, Mr. Wes Bryan.

7
00:00:29.470 --> 00:00:31.050
Wes, welcome back to the show,
how is it going today?

8
00:00:31.050 --> 00:00:35.140
>> It's going great and as always good to
be here with ITProTV and that's right we

9
00:00:35.140 --> 00:00:40.240
are continuing along with MDOP and today
we're gonna be looking at Virtualized

10

applications, or more correctly,
App V, application virtualization.

11
00:00:44.510 --> 00:00:48.990
Now, we had talked about
in other series about

virtualizing operating systems, and
I would definitely take a look at those.

13
00:00:53.870 --> 00:00:56.630
But we're gonna look at something a little
bit different today when it comes to

14

15
00:00:57.420 --> 00:01:00.395
A lot of us think about the whole
entire platform, right.

16
00:01:00.395 --> 00:01:03.103
We think about maybe something
like Microsoft Hyper-V

17
00:01:03.103 --> 00:01:05.586
if you're running any
client software out there.

18
00:01:05.586 --> 00:01:08.278
Maybe you're thinking of VirtualBox,
right.

19

Almost the same concept but
slightly different.

20
00:01:12.062 --> 00:01:17.319
So, let's go ahead and talk a little bit
about what scenario would make us even

21
00:01:17.319 --> 00:01:22.990
consider application virtualization at
the same time, we'll explain what it is.

22
00:01:22.990 --> 00:01:27.910
Now of the, of being a part of the
Microsoft Desktop Optimization Pack allows

23
00:01:27.910 --> 00:01:33.350
you to achieve something first and
foremost is Application co-exist.

24
00:01:33.350 --> 00:01:36.210
Just imagine the ability to virtualize or

25

sandbox an application so that it doesn't
interfere with other applications.

26
00:01:40.120 --> 00:01:42.740
Now, you might say well,
what is the benefit of that?

27
00:01:42.740 --> 00:01:45.440
Well, I want you to think about it
maybe having a hardware platform that

28
00:01:45.440 --> 00:01:47.940
an application doesn't natively run on.

29
00:01:47.940 --> 00:01:53.010
Maybe, it doesn't have for instance
you're running another application.

30
00:01:53.010 --> 00:01:54.869
Maybe you are in a test environment.

31
00:01:54.869 --> 00:01:58.594
Well., what could you do to get
an application running, right?

32
00:01:58.594 --> 00:02:00.790
What we could install Hyper-V, right.

33
00:02:00.790 --> 00:02:03.930
We could virtualize
the entire operating system.

34
00:02:03.930 --> 00:02:08.650
We could slip stream into that VHD,
the application itself.

35
00:02:08.650 --> 00:02:12.410
But I want you to consider what we
are doing, when we do that with hyperV.

00:02:12.410 --> 00:02:15.430
We're taking the entire
operating system and

37

38
00:02:18.730 --> 00:02:22.929
Other thing to keep in mind is that your

39
00:02:22.929 --> 00:02:25.042

40
00:02:25.042 --> 00:02:27.840
You need a 64 bit operating system.

Your CPU has to support either

AMDV so
I have to have a CPU that supports it.

43

Then, we've got things like resources,

If I wanna virtualize

I have to have 2 gigs of RAM for the host

46

47
00:02:46.640 --> 00:02:47.650
And it doesn't stop there,

48
00:02:47.650 --> 00:02:51.010
then I have to have enough resources
to run the application itself.

49
00:02:51.010 --> 00:02:53.280
So, there's a lot that we have to do.

50
00:02:53.280 --> 00:02:54.490
Now, could you do this?

51
00:02:54.490 --> 00:02:56.990
Absolutely, that's what it's there for,
that's why we have Hyper-V.

52
00:02:56.990 --> 00:03:01.760
But it does come with some specifications
that your machines have to meet.

53
00:03:01.760 --> 00:03:05.840
Now, image the ability to virtualize
the application itself and

54
00:03:05.840 --> 00:03:09.910

55
00:03:09.910 --> 00:03:10.650
That's 32 bit.

56
00:03:10.650 --> 00:03:15.390
That doesn't have the resources to
support a guest operating system and

57
00:03:15.390 --> 00:03:18.150
then the software that runs on it,
as well.

58
00:03:18.150 --> 00:03:20.290
Well, you might be saying,
well, Wes, you know what?

59
00:03:20.290 --> 00:03:22.270
How about we use remote app in Azure?

60
00:03:22.270 --> 00:03:23.310
You can certainly do that.

61
00:03:23.310 --> 00:03:26.600
In fact, that's where the trend is going

Cuz it doesn't matter what the application

64

the platform is, because it's running on
a server across the Internet in the cloud.

65
00:03:34.740 --> 00:03:37.780
But what if you're in
a managed environment?

66

What if you're in an environment where
you have to do testing on products that,

67
00:03:41.850 --> 00:03:44.700
well, don't allow you to
connect to the Internet?

68
00:03:44.700 --> 00:03:46.690
Well, now we've got an option here.

69
00:03:46.690 --> 00:03:50.510
Sure, if we wanna use something like
remote app, we have to have all the server

70
00:03:50.510 --> 00:03:54.990
infrastructure in place, set everything up
just to be able to test the application.

71
00:03:54.990 --> 00:03:58.820
So there are some limitations
to what you can do sometimes and

72
00:03:58.820 --> 00:04:01.010
that's where App-V comes into play for us.

73
00:04:01.010 --> 00:04:05.140
Dan, for instance, when you don't have the
resources on a machine to support Hyper-V.

74
00:04:05.140 --> 00:04:08.670
Again, for security purposes you need
to isolate the testing platform and

75

you can't connect outbound
to the Internet, well,

76
00:04:10.590 --> 00:04:12.520
that kind of negates being
able to use remote apps.

77
00:04:12.520 --> 00:04:16.220
So, Dan I would say that virtualization
in App-V does have its place and

78
00:04:16.220 --> 00:04:17.450
that's what we're gonna look at today.

79
00:04:17.450 --> 00:04:21.680
>> Yeah, it's a very pointed tool, but
it is another tool in our tool kit for

80

00:04:24.390 --> 00:04:26.460
And maybe that's few and far between.

82
00:04:26.460 --> 00:04:28.360
Maybe that's your daily environment.

83
00:04:28.360 --> 00:04:30.990
Who knows?
We just wanna give you guys resources that

84

85
00:04:35.490 --> 00:04:37.270
And now that you've sold us on it,
Wes, and
