publishing it out to computers.

540
00:28:40.510 --> 00:28:46.540
Now I have an MSI installer file, provided
I've got the application client running.

541
00:28:46.540 --> 00:28:50.130
So that takes me to the next
thing that we have to do Dan,

542
00:28:50.130 --> 00:28:52.600
but I do see that we are kind
of running out of time.

543
00:28:52.600 --> 00:28:55.490
I think I talked a little
bit too much on this one.

544
00:28:55.490 --> 00:28:59.470
So we do have to still install
the client on the machine.

545
00:28:59.470 --> 00:29:02.080
And that's called the application
virtualization client for

546
00:29:02.080 --> 00:29:05.330
it to be able to run that application,
but that's gonna take a little bit.

547
00:29:05.330 --> 00:29:07.580
So I'm not sure if we'll have
enough time in this one.

548
00:29:07.580 --> 00:29:08.420
>> Well you know what?

549
00:29:08.420 --> 00:29:08.970
Not a big deal.

550
00:29:08.970 --> 00:29:11.250
We can always come back and
do part two for that.

551
00:29:11.250 --> 00:29:14.010
And I don't know about you guys, but
I kinda wanna see how this ends.

552
00:29:14.010 --> 00:29:15.940
I wanna see the finished product.

553
00:29:15.940 --> 00:29:17.110
>> That's right.

554
00:29:17.110 --> 00:29:18.110
>> So that we can things.

555
00:29:18.110 --> 00:29:18.900
So that's what we'll do.

556
00:29:18.900 --> 00:29:20.060
We'll do a part two.

557
00:29:20.060 --> 00:29:23.000
We do thank you for
explaining up to this point thus far.

558
00:29:23.000 --> 00:29:24.300
We thank you guys for joining us.

559
00:29:24.300 --> 00:29:26.330
And hopefully we'll see you there as well.

560
00:29:26.330 --> 00:29:29.330
Signing off for ITPro.TV,
I've been your host Daniel Lowrie.

561
00:29:29.330 --> 00:29:30.100
>> And I'm Wes Bryan.

562
00:29:30.100 --> 00:29:31.905
We'll see you next time.

563
00:29:31.905 --> 00:29:39.810
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Wes continue their discussion on Microsoft's AppV. They jump back in by demonstrating the installation of the AppV client and then running the previously sequenced software along side an older version. Finally they look at editing AppV packages and the settings therein.
episodes.title: Application Virtualization Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.004 --> 00:00:16.828
All right, greetings everyone and welcome
to another exciting episode of ITProTV.

3
00:00:16.828 --> 00:00:20.939
I'm your host, Daniel Lowrie, and in
today's episode we are continuing on with

4
00:00:20.939 --> 00:00:23.512
our Microsoft Desktop Optimization Pack
series.

5
00:00:23.512 --> 00:00:28.416
Joining us back in the studio again today,
should I say, for a little part two

6
00:00:28.416 --> 00:00:32.815
on application virtualization is
our good friend, Mr. Wes Bryan.

7
00:00:32.815 --> 00:00:33.977
Wes, welcome back, sir, how's it going?

8
00:00:33.977 --> 00:00:38.049
>> It's going great, Dan, thanks and
as always good to be here with ITProTV and

9
00:00:38.049 --> 00:00:41.400
right part two of our
application virtualization.

10
00:00:41.400 --> 00:00:42.110
In the first part,

11
00:00:42.110 --> 00:00:45.690
one of the things that we took care
of was sequencing an application,

12
00:00:45.690 --> 00:00:49.740
well, really preparing a technician's
computer to even sequence and application.

13
00:00:49.740 --> 00:00:53.050
We made sure that some of
the prerequisites were taken care of,

14
00:00:53.050 --> 00:00:57.320
remember some of the services that needed
to be disabled, any pending restarts,

15
00:00:57.320 --> 00:01:00.720
to get our technician computer where it
needs to be so that when the application

16
00:01:00.720 --> 00:01:04.500
is sequenced, well,
the sequencing happens the way it should.

17
00:01:04.500 --> 00:01:08.140
So now we're into part two, and
what's the other side of the tracks?

18
00:01:08.140 --> 00:01:11.690
Well, that is running the application
virtualization client.

19
00:01:11.690 --> 00:01:15.010
Now, the client has to be
run on any target computer,

20
00:01:15.010 --> 00:01:16.560
that's gonna run a virtualized app.

21
00:01:16.560 --> 00:01:21.086
And that application virtualization
client is what really sandboxes and

22
00:01:21.086 --> 00:01:25.247
virtualizes this instance of this
application through things like

23
00:01:25.247 --> 00:01:30.290
virtualized application packages,
even its own virtualized registry system.

24
00:01:30.290 --> 00:01:33.063
So let's go ahead and
show you how to do that.

25
00:01:33.063 --> 00:01:37.379
Remember that you have to have your
App-V files out of the MDOP ISO,

26
00:01:37.379 --> 00:01:42.528
remember we have mounted that MDOP ISO,
and we extracted the App-V folder out,

27
00:01:42.528 --> 00:01:45.805
and we used the sequencer
in the first part of this.

28
00:01:45.805 --> 00:01:49.530
But now what we're gonna do is we're
actually gonna look at the client folder.

29
00:01:49.530 --> 00:01:52.050
Keep in mind that you do have
the documentation there if you

30
00:01:52.050 --> 00:01:53.010
need to read it.

31
00:01:53.010 --> 00:01:54.300
It comes in a few different languages and

32
00:01:54.300 --> 00:01:56.570
really just gives you
a link out to TechNet.

33
00:01:56.570 --> 00:01:57.410
So I'd recommend it.

34
00:01:57.410 --> 00:02:00.110
If this is the first time you've seen
this, definitely watch the videos, but

35
00:02:00.110 --> 00:02:02.950
definitely use those URLs
in the documentation.

36
00:02:02.950 --> 00:02:04.860
They are very helpful.

37
00:02:04.860 --> 00:02:05.850
Now, we're gonna go ahead and

38
00:02:05.850 --> 00:02:11.890
I'm just gonna pull the application
client executable here to the desktop.

39
00:02:11.890 --> 00:02:14.110
And we're gonna go ahead and
we're gonna run this.

40
00:02:14.110 --> 00:02:17.770
Notice that, well,
it's the same installer that we've seen.

41
00:02:17.770 --> 00:02:20.534
The difference is, well,
this is the client and not the sequencer.

42
00:02:20.534 --> 00:02:22.771
We'll go ahead and choose Install,

43
00:02:22.771 --> 00:02:27.910
we've got another EULA here that we've got
to accept and we're gonna choose next.

44
00:02:27.910 --> 00:02:31.430
Remember with the Customer Experience
Improvement Program you can opt in or

45
00:02:31.430 --> 00:02:33.190
opt out as you choose.

46
00:02:33.190 --> 00:02:35.060
And we're gonna choose Install.

47
00:02:35.060 --> 00:02:38.170
Now, one of the things that you might
notice is that you have to be a local

48
00:02:38.170 --> 00:02:41.060
administrator on the machine
to install the client,

49
00:02:41.060 --> 00:02:44.110
that is very important
standard users can not,

50
00:02:44.110 --> 00:02:48.810
so have this provision on your machines
prior to deploying an application so

51
00:02:48.810 --> 00:02:52.219
that the end user experience
really isn't hindered at all.

52
00:02:53.820 --> 00:02:58.400
And as it goes to the installation process
you'll see that the next thing that we're

53
00:02:58.400 --> 00:03:02.910
gonna do is we're going to
the virtualize package that we ran,

54
00:03:02.910 --> 00:03:06.940
we're gonna actually go ahead and
run that MSI file.

55
00:03:06.940 --> 00:03:11.610
So we extract it, when we ran
our sequencer we went ahead and

56
00:03:11.610 --> 00:03:14.990
put our virtualized application
here on the desktop,

57
00:03:14.990 --> 00:03:17.500
we'll see we have our MSI file here.

58
00:03:17.500 --> 00:03:23.100
And keep in mind that, remember, we
are running the 6.8.4 in the background.

59
00:03:23.100 --> 00:03:26.940
We'll go ahead and
install our virtualized app here.

60
00:03:26.940 --> 00:03:29.590
And, well, Dan,
it doesn't look like it did much there.

61
00:03:29.590 --> 00:03:32.030
[LAUGH] So we're gonna hope that it runs.

62
00:03:32.030 --> 00:03:34.780
Let's go ahead and
we'll get down into our Start menu.

63
00:03:34.780 --> 00:03:36.960
Notice there's a Recently added.

64
00:03:36.960 --> 00:03:37.950
I'll go ahead and look down.

65
00:03:37.950 --> 00:03:40.960
You can see the folder down here for
Notepad++.

66
00:03:40.960 --> 00:03:44.700
We're gonna launch that and
we've got a 6.9.1.

67
00:03:44.700 --> 00:03:48.926
Now, I do want to take a second here,
while we've got all these screens open and

68
00:03:48.926 --> 00:03:52.144
go ahead and open another screen,
[LAUGH] and we wanna look and

69
00:03:52.144 --> 00:03:53.869
see that we're still running.

70
00:03:53.869 --> 00:03:58.628
You'll see it over here, the 6.8.4 there,

71
00:03:58.628 --> 00:04:03.274
and that is actually
running in the background,

72
00:04:03.274 --> 00:04:06.830
side by side, with our 6.8.4.

73
00:04:06.830 --> 00:04:10.750
So we get that side-by-side
application coexistence.

74
00:04:10.750 --> 00:04:16.200
We can test this product out, the 6.9.1,
determine if we want to use it.

75
00:04:16.200 --> 00:04:17.460
At the same time,

76
00:04:17.460 --> 00:04:22.360
it's not interfering with the earlier
addition of this software.

77
00:04:22.360 --> 00:04:26.730
So really cool technology then,
to be able to test these

78
00:04:26.730 --> 00:04:31.100
applications side-by-side, but there are
some things that you also have to look at.

79
00:04:31.100 --> 00:04:33.164
So I'd like to just take a second here and

80
00:04:33.164 --> 00:04:37.070
talk a little bit about some of the
troubleshooting that you might run into.

81
00:04:38.120 --> 00:04:40.602
For instance, if you are troubleshooting,

82
00:04:40.602 --> 00:04:43.815
let me show you an Event Viewer
where you can go real quick.

83
00:04:43.815 --> 00:04:47.765
If we get down to Event Viewer, this
is gonna be, in some of the logs you've

84
00:04:47.765 --> 00:04:51.990
probably seen before, this is in the
Applications and Services log over here.

85
00:04:51.990 --> 00:04:54.870
And we can expand that out,
expand out Microsoft,

86
00:04:54.870 --> 00:04:59.000
and right here at the top, you'll see that
we have two different categories here.

87
00:04:59.000 --> 00:05:01.570
We've got client and sequencer.

88
00:05:01.570 --> 00:05:05.070
If we want,
we can get operational logs, find out.

89
00:05:05.070 --> 00:05:08.940
In admin logs, for instance,
I'm gonna see a handful of errors.

90
00:05:08.940 --> 00:05:10.520
We're moving packages and stuff.

91
00:05:10.520 --> 00:05:12.690
So if you are, for

92
00:05:12.690 --> 00:05:16.630
instance, troubleshooting App-V,
you can look at the administration side.

93
00:05:16.630 --> 00:05:20.110
The virtualized applications,
too, you can see that note.

94
00:05:20.110 --> 00:05:24.401
As far as the sequencer goes,
you also have administration options here.

95
00:05:24.401 --> 00:05:26.531
And we can look down
through those differend,

96
00:05:26.531 --> 00:05:29.490
it looks like we've got a whole
bunch of warnings going on here.

97
00:05:29.490 --> 00:05:33.410
And then, obviously,
we also have the operational log.

98
00:05:33.410 --> 00:05:37.050
So that's one place, remember
the App-V event logs that you can go,

99
00:05:37.050 --> 00:05:39.760
if you are troubleshooting some
of the other things, like for

100
00:05:39.760 --> 00:05:42.360
instance the sequencer itself,

101
00:05:42.360 --> 00:05:48.180
keep in mind when you're creating
a new application package,

102
00:05:48.180 --> 00:05:52.010
do you have things like for
instance is WIndows Defender active?

103
00:05:52.010 --> 00:05:55.270
Keep in mind,
if it is you do have to diable to service.

104
00:05:55.270 --> 00:05:58.032
Remember you don't really wanna
do this on a production machine,

105
00:05:58.032 --> 00:06:00.316
because you're obviously
disabling the anti virus.

106
00:06:00.316 --> 00:06:04.241
Antivirus, if you have a standalone
antivirus software that you're running,

107
00:06:04.241 --> 00:06:08.940
that would hinder the overall package
creation, again, could corrupt it.

108
00:06:08.940 --> 00:06:13.820
Remember how all the installation files
being copied to the sequencing computer.

109
00:06:13.820 --> 00:06:15.780
If you have additional application files,
and

110
00:06:15.780 --> 00:06:18.330
they do give you spot
during the sequencing.

111
00:06:18.330 --> 00:06:21.730
That if you do have an additional files
that you need to include the package,

112
00:06:21.730 --> 00:06:23.860
which I guess you just have to have
them on the machine before you start

113
00:06:23.860 --> 00:06:25.670
the sequencing process.

114
00:06:25.670 --> 00:06:28.630
Now, as far as the misconfiguration
of packages go,

115
00:06:28.630 --> 00:06:30.710
there are some things that
you have to worry about that.

116
00:06:30.710 --> 00:06:34.060
Most often you're gonna do just
the standard package creation.

117
00:06:36.180 --> 00:06:38.280
If you're using plug-ins,

118
00:06:38.280 --> 00:06:42.649
you have virtualized plug-ins
that talk to applications and

119
00:06:42.649 --> 00:06:47.279
they talk to a communication
pathway called a connection group.

120
00:06:47.279 --> 00:06:49.618
So if you are doing the add-ins and
plug-ins,

121
00:06:49.618 --> 00:06:52.905
make sure you have your connection
groups configured correctly.

122
00:06:52.905 --> 00:06:55.730
The other thing is
the MSI file themselves.

123
00:06:55.730 --> 00:06:58.980
If you do get a bad sequence stuff, if for

124
00:06:58.980 --> 00:07:02.720
some reason it doesn't run, you could be
looking at your original installer file.

125
00:07:02.720 --> 00:07:07.840
And I'm not talking about what the app
sequence or produces that MSI file,

126
00:07:07.840 --> 00:07:11.260
I'm talking the installation file of
the application if you were gonna

127
00:07:11.260 --> 00:07:12.700
install it locally.

128
00:07:12.700 --> 00:07:18.423
If that file is corrupted, then the
sequencing isn't gonna happen correctly.

129
00:07:18.423 --> 00:07:23.772
Make sure that the application
itself has finished its sequencing

130
00:07:23.772 --> 00:07:29.789
as part of the normal installation if
you have to do post configurations and

131
00:07:29.789 --> 00:07:33.629
you forget those that
could cause the problem.

132
00:07:33.629 --> 00:07:35.680
Again, we've already talked
about the additional files.

133
00:07:35.680 --> 00:07:39.773
Optimizing the package, if you
are streaming this over an unreliable or

134
00:07:39.773 --> 00:07:44.485
slow network, keep in mind that you can
optimize it for a slow network connection.

135
00:07:44.485 --> 00:07:49.406
And then, what happens if, for instance,
you decide, well, I'm restricting certain

136
00:07:49.406 --> 00:07:53.164
operating systems, or if you
are restricting operating systems and

137
00:07:53.164 --> 00:07:56.789
you only want it to run on a certain
version of an operating system,

138
00:07:56.789 --> 00:08:00.140
maybe you configured that wrong,
and let me show you.

139
00:08:00.140 --> 00:08:05.240
So Dan, now that we've got our
application package virtualized,

140
00:08:05.240 --> 00:08:07.620
what if we've made some mistakes?

141
00:08:07.620 --> 00:08:09.520
I might have to edit
that application file.

142
00:08:09.520 --> 00:08:11.440
Now, there's a couple different
ways that you could do this.

143
00:08:11.440 --> 00:08:13.580
Let me show you one way and
then I'll show you the easy way.

144
00:08:15.420 --> 00:08:17.438
If we go to our application
virtualization,

145
00:08:17.438 --> 00:08:22.570
you'll notice that there was an option
here that we kinda looked at, and

146
00:08:22.570 --> 00:08:28.220
that was this, the other option
to modify an existing package.

147
00:08:28.220 --> 00:08:30.650
Now, I could use this route.

148
00:08:30.650 --> 00:08:34.980
And what it's gonna do is, it's gonna ask
me to do this update an existing package,

149
00:08:34.980 --> 00:08:37.340
do I wanna edit or add a new application.

150
00:08:37.340 --> 00:08:39.157
And notice the screen
that it takes you to.

151
00:08:39.157 --> 00:08:43.701
Let me show something that's kinda easier
if you have the sequencer installed which

152
00:08:43.701 --> 00:08:48.120
you should in your sequencing machine
in your administrator machine.

153
00:08:48.120 --> 00:08:50.014
Notice that virtualized file.

154
00:08:50.014 --> 00:08:55.604
Well, if you look at that virtualized
file the one with the .appv extension,

155
00:08:55.604 --> 00:08:58.330
all I have to do is click on that.

156
00:08:58.330 --> 00:09:02.540
And notice that it's gonna start that
application sequencer process again.

157
00:09:02.540 --> 00:09:04.160
And it takes me right to the screen.

158
00:09:04.160 --> 00:09:06.220
And you skip all that process.

159
00:09:06.220 --> 00:09:09.471
I know it's only a couple of clicks,
but if you've got the App-V file and

160
00:09:09.471 --> 00:09:12.148
it is is located on the same
computer that your sequencer is,

161
00:09:12.148 --> 00:09:13.947
which it needs to be to modify it anyway.

162
00:09:13.947 --> 00:09:17.514
It's gonna know right away that, hey,
this is already an existing package, so

163
00:09:17.514 --> 00:09:19.360
I don't need to ask you those questions.

164
00:09:19.360 --> 00:09:23.290
Let's go ahead and open it up and
take you right to what you need to do.

165
00:09:23.290 --> 00:09:25.974
Again, I can update it,
I can edit the package, or

166
00:09:25.974 --> 00:09:27.791
add a new application if I need to.

167
00:09:27.791 --> 00:09:30.560
Let's go ahead and look real quick,
just plan that real quick,

168
00:09:30.560 --> 00:09:34.710
just briefly that's editing the package
and some things you can do with this.

169
00:09:34.710 --> 00:09:41.020
Now, it's asking me to point it to
the application itself, the package.

170
00:09:41.020 --> 00:09:44.340
And this is why I like
clicking on the file itself,

171
00:09:44.340 --> 00:09:49.080
I don't have to type this crazy long
path out as part of the Wizard.

172
00:09:49.080 --> 00:09:51.700
It already knew, it says, well,
I already know where that application is,

173
00:09:51.700 --> 00:09:54.260
you clicked on it so it's gotta be
in the location that you clicked on,

174
00:09:54.260 --> 00:09:57.790
and that makes it a lot easier for
Wes there [LAUGH].

175
00:09:57.790 --> 00:10:00.920
Now, when the editor comes up,

176
00:10:00.920 --> 00:10:05.070
you get a few series of tabs and
options that you can use.

177
00:10:05.070 --> 00:10:07.428
Properties, you can see GUID.

178
00:10:07.428 --> 00:10:09.383
Every piece of software has a GUID,

179
00:10:09.383 --> 00:10:13.830
that string of numbers globally unique
that identifies the software, itself.

180
00:10:13.830 --> 00:10:17.550
And then,
the packaged version of the GUID.

181
00:10:17.550 --> 00:10:19.420
Now, here's where we're
talking about deployment.

182
00:10:19.420 --> 00:10:23.850
Let's say notice that the architecture
says Any Operating System here.

183
00:10:23.850 --> 00:10:28.020
Well, what if I wanted to restrict this or
maybe I have restricted it to only certain

184
00:10:28.020 --> 00:10:32.840
editions of Windows and then certain
platforms, architecture specifically.

185
00:10:32.840 --> 00:10:37.680
Well, again, if I've configured this
wrong, maybe for instance I put Windows 7

186
00:10:37.680 --> 00:10:43.590
32 bit, notice that it's
given me an error right here.

187
00:10:43.590 --> 00:10:47.248
It says, hey, you should sequence this
with the earliest version in the operating

188
00:10:47.248 --> 00:10:48.562
system in your environment.

189
00:10:48.562 --> 00:10:52.553
But if I take this and
let's take Windows 7 out, and

190
00:10:52.553 --> 00:10:55.386
again we put Windows 8.1 in here.

191
00:10:55.386 --> 00:11:00.350
Notice it didn't give me a hard time about
that because this sequencer says, yeah,

192
00:11:00.350 --> 00:11:01.720
I know Windows 8.1.

193
00:11:01.720 --> 00:11:04.390
I'm as close to that as
you pretty much come.

194
00:11:04.390 --> 00:11:05.970
So there's no problem.

195
00:11:05.970 --> 00:11:09.360
That could be something that causes
a problem in your deployment or

196
00:11:09.360 --> 00:11:10.810
your virtualized applications.

197
00:11:10.810 --> 00:11:13.850
I'm just gonna leave it to any
operating system here, and

198
00:11:13.850 --> 00:11:14.920
it makes it a little easier for me.

199
00:11:14.920 --> 00:11:15.970
But keep that in mind.

200
00:11:15.970 --> 00:11:20.040
You can see that some of the things
that come up, as part of that process.

201
00:11:20.040 --> 00:11:22.240
Now, what if Dan wants to
audit the change history?

202
00:11:22.240 --> 00:11:25.020
What if I have made a couple of changes,
and something isn't going right?

203
00:11:25.020 --> 00:11:28.427
And Dan wants not to point the finger,
but for audit purposes?

204
00:11:28.427 --> 00:11:29.385
>> Not for pointing the finger [LAUGH].

205
00:11:29.385 --> 00:11:31.788
>> Not for pointing the finger,
only for pointing the finger.

206
00:11:31.788 --> 00:11:33.448
[LAUGH] Well,
we could go to the change history.

207
00:11:33.448 --> 00:11:37.740
And what's kinda cool about this, is it
says, hey, Wes was the one that did it.

208
00:11:37.740 --> 00:11:40.060
I can't turn around and
say non-repediation.

209
00:11:40.060 --> 00:11:42.301
I can turn around and say Dan,
I don't know what you're talking about,

210
00:11:42.301 --> 00:11:43.277
it wasn't me that changed it.

211
00:11:43.277 --> 00:11:46.758
And he can say, well, Dan,
there's the information here, so

212
00:11:46.758 --> 00:11:49.091
if anybody misconfigured it, it was you.

213
00:11:49.091 --> 00:11:53.938
[LAUGH] And you can see the operating
system version that it was sequenced

214
00:11:53.938 --> 00:11:57.250
on and that's a good information to know.

215
00:11:57.250 --> 00:12:03.460
The Windows version, here you can
see what processor family it was,

216
00:12:03.460 --> 00:12:06.570
terminal services, and the .NET framework.

217
00:12:06.570 --> 00:12:10.110
So basically it gets the metadata
about the change history.

218
00:12:10.110 --> 00:12:11.942
Virtual registry, now this is really cool.

219
00:12:11.942 --> 00:12:15.500
This is kinda shows you under the hood
what's going on with application

220
00:12:15.500 --> 00:12:16.230
virtualization.

221
00:12:16.230 --> 00:12:20.310
It's creating this virtualized registry,
and that's how it kinda sandboxes it.

222
00:12:20.310 --> 00:12:21.740
But when I look in here,

223
00:12:21.740 --> 00:12:26.150
if I choose to, notice that what
I'm seeing here is nothing more

224
00:12:26.150 --> 00:12:30.230
than any other registry hibe that you
would see down there in the registry.

225
00:12:30.230 --> 00:12:33.300
Which is a good thing that you
could see that information.

226
00:12:33.300 --> 00:12:36.700
And you could see some of the settings
if you needed to, down here.

227
00:12:36.700 --> 00:12:38.030
Package files.

228
00:12:38.030 --> 00:12:41.651
Any of the files that are included inside
of this package if you have to use this

229
00:12:41.651 --> 00:12:44.880
for many troubleshooting or
debugging you can see that.

230
00:12:44.880 --> 00:12:46.600
There aren't any of virtualized services.

231
00:12:46.600 --> 00:12:49.090
And if you do want to,
be careful with this one.

232
00:12:49.090 --> 00:12:51.580
If you do wanna allow it to
communicate with the host,

233
00:12:51.580 --> 00:12:56.520
you do have the option to allow the named
objects to interact with the local system.

234
00:12:56.520 --> 00:12:59.530
But do keep in mind that now you're
breaking the benefits of why you would

235
00:12:59.530 --> 00:13:04.180
even be using application
virtualization in the first place.

236
00:13:04.180 --> 00:13:08.940
So I could make my edits to that,
I could do all my changes, and

237
00:13:08.940 --> 00:13:11.050
then close it down and we are good.

238
00:13:11.050 --> 00:13:16.400
So it gives you the ability
to modify the package.

239
00:13:16.400 --> 00:13:20.085
I think, Dan, one of the last things I
would mention are some of the benefits,

240
00:13:20.085 --> 00:13:23.290
kinda sum it up, why would we use this.

241
00:13:23.290 --> 00:13:27.299
Keep in mind one of the biggest benefits
is isolation from the operating system.

242
00:13:27.299 --> 00:13:34.520
All right, less resource consumption than
a full virtualized machine, a full VM.

243
00:13:34.520 --> 00:13:38.580
I don't have to virtualized the whole
entire operating system, and

244
00:13:38.580 --> 00:13:40.290
then the application co-existence.

245
00:13:40.290 --> 00:13:44.530
So now keep in mind, with any benefit
there's gonna be a little bit of a cost.

246
00:13:44.530 --> 00:13:48.130
The cost is that it does run locally,
it does consume local resources.

247
00:13:48.130 --> 00:13:50.120
Unlike some other
technologies that we have.

248
00:13:50.120 --> 00:13:53.360
Like for instance, Cloud based
solution where you connect out to

249
00:13:53.360 --> 00:13:56.810
the Internet there and they're running
them out in handy dandy clown, keep in

250
00:13:56.810 --> 00:14:00.340
mind there's a running on servers that
are hosted on somebody's else network so

251
00:14:00.340 --> 00:14:02.130
it doesn't run on the local resources.

252
00:14:02.130 --> 00:14:06.142
So that's something to keep in mind that
if you are gonna deploy your application

253
00:14:06.142 --> 00:14:09.741
to local machines rather than using
some kinda software as the service,

254
00:14:09.741 --> 00:14:13.163
your machines are gonna have to
support the application because they

255
00:14:13.163 --> 00:14:16.762
will be running locally even though
they are isolated from one another.

256
00:14:16.762 --> 00:14:21.643
And that gives you a good idea of why you
might use application virtualization over

257
00:14:21.643 --> 00:14:24.684
something like Hyper-V or
even Azure Remote App,

258
00:14:24.684 --> 00:14:29.633
especially with the Azure Remote App is
that you can't connect to the Internet, so

259
00:14:29.633 --> 00:14:31.510
I have no access to that.

260
00:14:31.510 --> 00:14:32.880
This gives you an alternative and

261
00:14:32.880 --> 00:14:36.250
a managed environment that doesn't
require an Internet connection.

262
00:14:36.250 --> 00:14:40.680
So cost and benefits, weigh the pros and

263
00:14:40.680 --> 00:14:43.960
the cons and hopefully,
this will help you out in deploying and

264
00:14:43.960 --> 00:14:48.160
understanding a little bit more about
the application virtualization software.

265
00:14:48.160 --> 00:14:51.310
>> Well, Wes, you've definitely
taken us through the gamut of things

266
00:14:51.310 --> 00:14:52.200
that we'll need to know.

267
00:14:52.200 --> 00:14:55.470
It wasn't just a, well, you install
this and you make a package and

268
00:14:55.470 --> 00:14:56.750
then you run it and it's great!

269
00:14:56.750 --> 00:14:58.680
Yeah, we did do that, as well.

270
00:14:58.680 --> 00:15:00.130
That's always a good part.

271
00:15:00.130 --> 00:15:04.350
But you did a great job of showing us some
of the pitfalls that we might come across,

272
00:15:04.350 --> 00:15:07.070
some of the stumbling blocks that
would make this difficult for

273
00:15:07.070 --> 00:15:11.850
us, you kinda did all the cool,
the hard leg work should I say, for us so

274
00:15:11.850 --> 00:15:15.170
that we don't have to trudge
through that ourselves.

275
00:15:15.170 --> 00:15:16.730
And that, we appreciate you for.

276
00:15:16.730 --> 00:15:20.670
Thank you so much, and we thank you for
dropping by and explaining App-V for us,

277
00:15:20.670 --> 00:15:24.130
maybe it's something we wanna deploy
in our environment if we want to,

278
00:15:24.130 --> 00:15:25.810
now we actually can.

279
00:15:25.810 --> 00:15:28.790
But looking at the clock it's time for
us to sign off.

280
00:15:28.790 --> 00:15:31.550
For ITProTV, I've been your host,
Daniel Lowrie.

281
00:15:31.550 --> 00:15:32.340
>> And I'm Wes Bryan.

282
00:15:32.340 --> 00:15:33.639
>> We'll see you next time.

283
00:15:33.639 --> 00:15:40.257
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Wes introduce you to MDOP's User Experience Virtualization. They begin by describing what UE-V is as well as its similarities and differences to Folder Redirection and/or Roaming Profile. Then they explain all the components of the UE-V system and then move to preparing the environment for the UE-V deployment.
episodes.title: User Experience Virtualization
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.206 --> 00:00:16.119
All right, greetings everyone and
welcome to another exciting episode of

3
00:00:16.119 --> 00:00:20.341
IT Pro TV I'm your host Daniel Lowrie and
in today's episode we are continuing on

4
00:00:20.341 --> 00:00:23.630
with our Microsoft Desktop
Optimization Pack series.

5
00:00:23.630 --> 00:00:25.920
And, wow I almost ran out of breath
saying that because it's such a long

6
00:00:25.920 --> 00:00:26.830
introduction.

7
00:00:26.830 --> 00:00:29.280
But, it is the MDOP for short.

8
00:00:29.280 --> 00:00:32.320
Joining us back in the studio
again today to lend his expertise

9
00:00:32.320 --> 00:00:35.260
on that very topic is our good friend,
Mr. Wes Bryant.

10
00:00:35.260 --> 00:00:37.140
Wes, welcome back to the show,
how's it going sir?

11
00:00:37.140 --> 00:00:38.090
>> It's going great man.

12
00:00:38.090 --> 00:00:40.632
I have to tell you that is
the beauty of acronyms,

13
00:00:40.632 --> 00:00:43.988
it does make it a little bit easier for
us to talk about our topic.

14
00:00:43.988 --> 00:00:47.044
So, I'm going to go ahead and
I'm just going to abbreviate it and

15
00:00:47.044 --> 00:00:49.000
say we're going to be talking about UEV.

16
00:00:49.000 --> 00:00:49.570
What is UEV?

17
00:00:49.570 --> 00:00:53.410
Well, UEV is the User Experience
Virtualization technology, and

18
00:00:53.410 --> 00:00:56.580
you might be asking yourself, well,
what is it and why would we need it.

19
00:00:56.580 --> 00:00:59.830
Well, we hope to show you that
very thing here in this episode.

20
00:00:59.830 --> 00:01:02.640
I want to go ahead and kinda set
the stage for other technologies that we

21
00:01:02.640 --> 00:01:06.550
have that already do some of the same
things that UEV does for us.

22
00:01:06.550 --> 00:01:13.770
And, understanding that can explain why
we would even use UEV in the first place.

23
00:01:13.770 --> 00:01:17.130
Now, one of the things that UEV does
is it helps us to synchronize certain

24
00:01:17.130 --> 00:01:21.105
application settings across multiple
devices inside of a domain environment.

25
00:01:21.105 --> 00:01:24.255
Now, some of you that have been around
the domain environment for a little bit

26
00:01:24.255 --> 00:01:28.235
probably recognize a traditional
technique called roaming profiles.

27
00:01:28.235 --> 00:01:28.895
In fact, Dan and

28
00:01:28.895 --> 00:01:32.242
I were just talking about this prior
to the episode even starting, right?

29
00:01:32.242 --> 00:01:35.152
With roaming profiles you don't
really get to pick and choose, right.

30
00:01:35.152 --> 00:01:38.972
If I want settings to be synchronized
across all of the different client

31
00:01:38.972 --> 00:01:43.302
machines that are end user suited
then roam the entire profile.

32
00:01:43.302 --> 00:01:48.035
And, that includes not just certain
settings, but all of your settings, right?

33
00:01:48.035 --> 00:01:51.310
And, also includes things
like your data as well.

34
00:01:51.310 --> 00:01:55.900
Well, the problem with roaming profiles
is it can chew up a lot of space.

35
00:01:55.900 --> 00:02:00.830
If you've got a bunch of end users that
are going to use roaming profiles,

36
00:02:00.830 --> 00:02:03.600
well you can start chewing up hard
drive space on your file server,

37
00:02:03.600 --> 00:02:06.220
wherever it is that you keep
these roaming profiles.

38
00:02:06.220 --> 00:02:09.004
The thing about roaming profiles as well,

39
00:02:09.004 --> 00:02:13.910
is the fact that you don't synchronize
settings until the user logs off.

40
00:02:13.910 --> 00:02:17.650
Once the user logs off, then those
settings will be synchronized up to their

41
00:02:17.650 --> 00:02:22.000
location there, up to that file server,
that intermediate store.

42
00:02:22.000 --> 00:02:25.580
Here's another thing with roaming profiles
that can sometimes cause a problem.

43
00:02:25.580 --> 00:02:29.060
If the person doesn't log out of
the machine before they roam or

44
00:02:29.060 --> 00:02:32.960
move to the next machine, and they log in,
the settings aren't synchronized.

45
00:02:32.960 --> 00:02:37.470
So, there are some limitations to
what roaming profiles allow us.

46
00:02:37.470 --> 00:02:40.200
Roaming profiles, we don't get to pick and
choose what settings.

47
00:02:40.200 --> 00:02:41.590
It's all or nothing.

48
00:02:41.590 --> 00:02:44.020
The other thing too is if we
have network problems, right.

49
00:02:44.020 --> 00:02:46.425
We have network bandwidth issues
it could take a little bit for

50
00:02:46.425 --> 00:02:48.815
those settings to synchronize
back down to a machine.

51
00:02:48.815 --> 00:02:51.215
So, what are some other
things that we can do?

52
00:02:51.215 --> 00:02:53.545
Well, we can implement folder redirection,
right?

53
00:02:53.545 --> 00:02:57.025
But, the problem is,
folder redirection only redirects data,

54
00:02:57.025 --> 00:02:59.405
it does very little to settings.

55
00:02:59.405 --> 00:03:01.705
All right, so
with that setting the stage there.

56
00:03:01.705 --> 00:03:07.110
That's where UEV helps us to try and
Get the best of

57
00:03:07.110 --> 00:03:12.290
both technologies without severely
degrading our network performance.

58
00:03:12.290 --> 00:03:15.910
And, really when it comes down to it,
the user experience that is sitting

59
00:03:15.910 --> 00:03:19.400
down at that computer expecting
those settings to be present.

60
00:03:19.400 --> 00:03:20.600
Now, no pun intended.

61
00:03:20.600 --> 00:03:21.650
So, let's go ahead and

62
00:03:21.650 --> 00:03:25.489
let's kind of dive into some of the
components that you can see here in, and

63
00:03:25.489 --> 00:03:29.705
that you'll need to implement the user
experience virtualization technology.

64
00:03:29.705 --> 00:03:32.790
S, I've got a little
diagram pulled up here, and

65
00:03:32.790 --> 00:03:36.140
these are the major
components that you need.

66
00:03:36.140 --> 00:03:37.440
You need a domain controller, right?

67
00:03:37.440 --> 00:03:39.180
You need a valid Windows domain.

68
00:03:39.180 --> 00:03:42.980
This does work on group policy settings,
which we'll look at coming up.

69
00:03:42.980 --> 00:03:44.980
The other thing that you
need is a file server.

70
00:03:44.980 --> 00:03:48.560
Now, the file server is
just a traditional server.

71
00:03:48.560 --> 00:03:49.630
Nothing special about it.

72
00:03:49.630 --> 00:03:55.450
You need a centralized location to store
the settings within these applications.

73
00:03:55.450 --> 00:03:57.870
Now, the other thing that we have
here is a management workstation.

74
00:03:57.870 --> 00:04:00.750
Now, I'll tell you that the management
workstation is kind of optional,

75
00:04:00.750 --> 00:04:03.900
and what I mean by that is
not that you don't need one.

76
00:04:03.900 --> 00:04:07.866
It doesn't have to a dedicated machine
because the Management Workstation is

77
00:04:07.866 --> 00:04:09.630
where you're going to create and

78
00:04:09.630 --> 00:04:14.010
customize what are known as
settings location templates.

79
00:04:14.010 --> 00:04:18.420
Now, it is an optional component to
have this, so you don't need it.

80
00:04:18.420 --> 00:04:22.710
If you have an administrative workstation
that you sit at, it's perfectly fine.

81
00:04:22.710 --> 00:04:24.330
You can use it as your
Management Workstation.

82
00:04:24.330 --> 00:04:29.530
Because really, when it comes down to it,
you're not managing the entire UEV Suite.

83
00:04:29.530 --> 00:04:33.210
What you're managing really is just
customized settings location templates.

84
00:04:33.210 --> 00:04:36.130
And, we'll dive in, we'll clarify
what that means here in a second.

85
00:04:36.130 --> 00:04:39.590
>> Now, Wes, really quickly, it seems
like, just from what you've said so far,

86
00:04:39.590 --> 00:04:42.640
maybe we just haven't gotten this far,
but it seems like this is a domain

87
00:04:42.640 --> 00:04:46.370
only function that this must be
being done inside of a domain.

88
00:04:46.370 --> 00:04:47.490
Is that the truth or

89
00:04:47.490 --> 00:04:49.400
can we do it inside a workstation or-
>> That's a very good

90
00:04:49.400 --> 00:04:51.071
>> Workspace as well?

91
00:04:51.071 --> 00:04:52.200
>> [CROSSTALK]
>> [LAUGH]

92
00:04:52.200 --> 00:04:53.440
>> No, that's a very good point.

93
00:04:53.440 --> 00:04:56.370
It has to be a domain, because
the way you deploy these settings and

94
00:04:56.370 --> 00:04:58.070
the way you control UEV.

95
00:04:58.070 --> 00:05:01.140
Even though we say the Management
Workstation, this is really going to

96
00:05:01.140 --> 00:05:04.700
be controlled through
the Domain Controller itself, right?

97
00:05:04.700 --> 00:05:07.710
You got to your DC, you implement
your group policy objects, and

98
00:05:07.710 --> 00:05:10.090
then you push out your settings
to all these computers.

99
00:05:10.090 --> 00:05:14.730
Which, to Dan's question there is
why we need domain joined clients,

100
00:05:14.730 --> 00:05:15.530
keep that in mind.

101
00:05:15.530 --> 00:05:16.666
So, we do need a domain here.

102
00:05:16.666 --> 00:05:20.210
Now, let's kind of look
at what the different

103
00:05:20.210 --> 00:05:22.990
roles are that are performed
by each one of these devices.

104
00:05:22.990 --> 00:05:24.822
So, we can just dive a little bit farther.

105
00:05:24.822 --> 00:05:28.680
Kind of understand what the components
are, the platform behind the scenes.

106
00:05:28.680 --> 00:05:30.960
Now, the first one is
the domain controller, right?

107
00:05:30.960 --> 00:05:34.070
If you're familiar with
an Active Directory Domain,

108
00:05:34.070 --> 00:05:35.820
you know what the domain controller does.

109
00:05:35.820 --> 00:05:40.650
But, as it relates to the user
experience virtualization technology,

110
00:05:40.650 --> 00:05:44.070
remember UEV, answering
a question does require a domain.

111
00:05:44.070 --> 00:05:45.620
Active Directory User and Computers.

112
00:05:45.620 --> 00:05:48.560
Now, you might say, well why do we need
active directory users in computers?

113
00:05:48.560 --> 00:05:53.200
Well, you're going to have to create
groups in order to push out the settings.

114
00:05:53.200 --> 00:05:56.710
You don't really have to, but
it is a good thing to have.

115
00:05:56.710 --> 00:06:01.160
Certain groups, remember role-based access
control, and so that you can manage that.

116
00:06:01.160 --> 00:06:05.200
The other thing that is we have the GPMC,
the group policy management console, and

117
00:06:05.200 --> 00:06:07.580
that's where you're going to
configure the group policy settings.

118
00:06:07.580 --> 00:06:12.220
Now, that being said, you can't
control the group policy settings if

119
00:06:12.220 --> 00:06:13.990
you don't have the group
policy templates in place.

120
00:06:13.990 --> 00:06:16.440
And like we've shown you in
the some of the past for instance,

121
00:06:16.440 --> 00:06:21.480
the Microsoft Bit Locker Administration
and Monitoring episode that we did, right?

122
00:06:21.480 --> 00:06:24.990
We had to take the MDOP active
directory templates for

123
00:06:24.990 --> 00:06:26.560
the technology that we're looking at, and

124
00:06:26.560 --> 00:06:31.470
we had to import them into the active
directory policies and definitions store.

125
00:06:31.470 --> 00:06:33.070
And, that's something that we're
going to show you as well.

126
00:06:33.070 --> 00:06:34.000
Getting that setup.

127
00:06:34.000 --> 00:06:37.900
We'll show you how to prepare your active
directory domain in order to deploy this.

128
00:06:37.900 --> 00:06:40.890
Now the file server, where your store is,

129
00:06:40.890 --> 00:06:43.310
there's not really too much flashy here,
Dan.

130
00:06:43.310 --> 00:06:45.080
There's not a lot of flare in this.

131
00:06:45.080 --> 00:06:46.870
When it comes to the file server,

132
00:06:46.870 --> 00:06:49.720
this is where the settings
location storage path, all right?

133
00:06:49.720 --> 00:06:53.010
Where are we going to store
something called settings packages?

134
00:06:53.010 --> 00:06:55.970
And, we'll talk a little more
about those coming up too.

135
00:06:55.970 --> 00:07:01.220
And then, another thing something known
as the settings template catalog.

136
00:07:01.220 --> 00:07:03.420
This is an optional component, and

137
00:07:03.420 --> 00:07:07.260
one of the things I want you to understand
as we go ahead and dive into this.

138

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Wes continue demonstrating how to deploy the User Experience Virtualization system. Here they pick up by showing you step-by-step how to install the UE-V Generator. Then they create customized settings location templates. Finally, they configure the UE-V Group Policy settings.

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Wes finish demonstrating how to deploy the User Experience Virtualization system. Here they prepare the client computer by installing the UE-V agent. Then they test the UE-V system by changing some settings and checking their persistence. Finally they open up the Company Settings Center and look at the options available there.
